description:
This is my go-to bakery for egg tarts and bbq buns! I usually speak to the workers in Cantonese, but some of the workers understand English too (you can also just point to the item). 

The place is pretty small so even though there's some chairs, I wouldn't consider this a sit-down place. I'd recommend coming here and trying out their other baked goods! They're decently priced and have a variety to choose from.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Mmm Chinese baked goods-- if I lived in Hong Kong, I'd definitely be eating these every day.

Writing this review is giving me a little bit of nostalgia. Up until 1.5 months ago, I worked right next to SF Chinatown, and I really never took advantage of the short distance here to get all my favorite comfort foods when things at the office weren't going so well. Now that I'm far away, it's hard to know the next time I'll make it back.

My mom happened to be SF last week and picked up some barbecue pork buns (cha siu bao) from here. The bread was appropriately soft, but lacked that sweet edge that really makes Chinese pastries. Good toasty brown color on the outside. The pork itself was in decent portion, had some chewy bits in it that make pork buns so yummy. Overall a solid 3.5/5 for me.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I am here solely for the reviews of the durian buns!! If you love durian, you will love this bakery. I literally make the trip go SF just for these and come back home with dozens. I always call ahead when ordering a lot so they know how much to prepare. 
I went by a couple days ago and they gave me the ones fresh out the ovens!! It was still warm and the bread was sooo soft. Not only that, there was plenty of durian inside!! It sucks that it tends to go to one side but just rip it in half and move the bread around. My absolute guilty pleasure and I always bring some back for my friends too. People who love durian love this. Yum yum yum! Parking sucks because it is on hills and china town is ALWAYS busy, but don't be intimidated! I always go on weekdays :) their egg tarts are also good!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
My sons always request Hot Dog Bread. When Good Mong Kok (a few doors down) run out as they always do, this place is a great alternative. I always get a egg tart for myself and both items are only $.90 each.

The clientele are mostly elderly and I enjoy observing their interactions and the items they buy.
author: Christina W.

description: This bakery is pretty cheap, but what is going on with their BBQ pork buns?! There is SO little filling...Clement BBQ has become my standard for pork buns since they always have huge buns with hella pork inside. Napoleon's pork sung sliced bread loaf also lacks pork sung, most of the side pieces don't have any filling. They do have a wide variety of baked goods, but come on, get your BBQ pork buns right - that is such a staple item for Chinese bakeries!
author: Angela C.

description: I ordered cake over the phone and picked up there. Very reasonable price, fast and delicious. Not like very pretty and full of people in the store but cake was good, staff was nice and the po-lo bread was delicious too. Just the word was a bit ugly.
author: Anya C.

description:
It's loud in here and there's like hella grannies and aunties in here tryna get their buns so it's really hard to flag down someone to get help.

Ordering my wedding cake was pretty frustrating but after waiting some minutes and letting them know I'm trying to order my wedding cake, eventually someone dropped what they were doing to help me cuz obviously a wedding cake = $$$$$.

I shopped around for the best priced cake and Napoleon had the best deal, my cake was simple, only 2 colors and 5 layers so I figured they can't F that up, it's easy peasy lemon squeezy stuff.

My cake was very wallet friendly and even with the delivery fee, it was cheaper than AA bakery across the street. You just have to deal with some rude ladies behind the counter, that's your tradeoff.

They got the cake colors right and the ribbon on it was fine but they decided to add little dots around my cake for no damn reason. WTF? The dots were tacky and ugly but I didn't stress about it too much during the wedding as it'd going to be deconstructed later anyways. But now looking back, WTF? They didn't consult with me, I only saw the finished product when they delivered it to me on my wedding day, an hour before my reception started. I gave them a picture of the cake and gave them clear instructions. See pictures.
 
3 stars is because it was affordable but I hated the extra dots on my cake and the rude ladies you have to deal with.
author: Kelly L.

description: This is my childhood bakery right here. My family has been buying baked goods from them for 20+ years and they never disappoint. We have probably spent thousands of dollars there over the years. I love this place from the bottom of my heart. You can get anything there and it would be delicious. Everything is made fresh and in house.  There's no real line there so it can be hard to get your order in especially for noobs and tourists but it'll be all worth it once you bite down into that fresh warm delicious pastry that just came outta the oven. Happy eating!
author: Lily F.

description:
Don't come here! Everything they have here are so dirty!!! I had a diarreha after eating their egg tar here.

I know, it's chinatown, you're expecting to get cheap stuff here, and your expectation for getting high quality items here is low. But wait, it doesn't mean they can use that as an execuse to make you sick! No, that's not accetable at all.

I can tell from their outside and inside, this place is super super dirty. I thought it didn't bother me becuase I am just getting some food here, not like I am gonna be licking the tables or anything. WRONG! If the ourside where the customers can see is so dirty already, OMG, can you imagine how dirty it is inside the kitchen? Jesus, my stomach started to hurt 20 min after eating their food. Honesetly I have no idea how they pass the food safety test.

I would never come back again! I would also tell all my friends to avoid this place! I am sharing my story here so that you won't be the next victim.
author: Lydia O.

description:
So, it took a while to actually garner the attention of one of the employees to order, but we eventually did and thankfully I had a Toisanese speaker with me.  I'm sure you can also easily order in English too but it always helps to have a native speaker!

I have no idea how their baked buns are but the egg tarts (of which, I might even consider myself a connoisseur) were delicious.  Really flaky crust with a not-too-sweet egg custard filling.  Definitely an easy substitute for the crazy lines at Golden Gate Bakery.  And they are more affordable, too!  Only 90 cents each!  I will definitely return to get my egg tart (Dan Ta) fix!
author: Jess Y.

description: What a hidden gem!!  We live down the Peninsula and don't come up to SF Chinatown often anymore since my childhood is literally disappearing before my very eyes.  I wandered in with my son the other day and everything we bought was delish!  Egg tart (filling was luscious & not soggy, crust was buttery & flakey), curry puffs (yummy), onion bread, hot dog buns, custard buns & something from my childhood I can't remember the name for but it was on top of the counter in a wrapped package.  Think rice crispy treat Asian style.  Sticky, chewy, yummy goodness.  Worth the drive up!!  Looking forward our next trip there!!
author: Lily C.

description:
Favorite bakery in Chinatown. If you're new to the Chinese bakery game, get the pineapple bun(bo lo bao) or the BBQ bun(cha sew bao). The pineapple bun is the perfect fluffiness with the right amount of flaky top crust without falling apart. The BBQ buns are soft but not full of air. The pork is cool perfectly with right amount of sauce, and not full of just pork fat. 

If you don't speak Chinese, it might be harder to get the attention of the ladies getting your buns. So make your way to the front so they get your attention because it's not self serve style. Be prepared to get pushed around by grouchy older folks who just want to get their buns. 

I got four BBQ buns for 3.60, they're 0.99 each but if you buy them in sets of 3, 6, 9, etc you get a deal on them. Each bun has its own deal, so make sure you ask them how they're sold. I also wanted to get the pineapple buns, but they ran out and it was only 2 o'clock. They usually don't run out until near closing time when they stop baking in the back. TIP: If you come right around closing, you can a discount because they're trying to push out all the buns. 

TLDR; All your authentic Chinese bun cravings can be satisfied here.
author: Sophia L.

description: Came a few more times after the last visit. I guess I was wrong. Only the younger girl who worked here was nice. That's it. Everyone else is so rude! They rush you to make your decision, when you say something, they tell you in a mean way that what you just said was wrong even though it's because they misunderstood you. Enough is enough, will never come back. The senior lady who works here is super bossy and super rude.
author: Louise K.

description: It was such a mistake to even walk into here. Super rude people and horrible experience. Would never come back again. The owners should train their employees to respect customers. Worst experience ever!
author: James M.

description:
I would say that this is my go-to Hong Kong-style bakery, but that's an understatement: these are the best buns I have had in this country. Admittedly, I don't seek out Chinese bakeries across the US, but my point is that I have only found better buns in Toronto and Hong Kong.

Their pineapple custard buns and pineapple red bean buns are my favorites, but their various coconut buns and baked and steamed BBQ pork buns are all also good. The egg tarts, when fresh, are also good. I kind of know what I like so I honestly haven't tried most of the rest of their display case, but I just assume that the rest is of equal quality. And everything is cheap.

If you're already at Good Mong Kok a few doors down, you might as well pass through here as well.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Cash only.

$.80 for an egg tart and so so delicious. Great ratio between custard and crust with such flaky crust.

Red bean pineapple bun is OK. The red bean isn't fully crushed so uneven consistency
author: Mimi T.

description:
One of my favorite bakeries in Chinatown. My family comes here for the mini sponge cakes, mini pineapple buns with either red bean or custard filling, and their loaves of bread with either custard or coconut. I also like to get the cheese chicken bun and the ham + corn bun. The cheese and chicken bun has a breaded chicken patty baked into the middle and is topped with cheese and a bit of tomato sauce. The ham and corn bun is soft and sweet. 

Prices are very reasonable. It can get quite busy, but they work fast and have a couple of workers behind the counter. Only a few small tables and chairs.
author: Anna L.

description:
Another review for this place ! My wedding cake turned out AMAZING !  Thank you to my friend who did not stress enough about giving them a picture of how you wanted the cake style so they font decide to do something else helped out! I'm sad that  her cake didn't work out but mines did. 

The cake was a hit, each person wanted more than 2 slices of cake! The size was pretty good, for a party of 270, there was enough to  go around with a three teir cake. I like things simple, so all I had was them to put on my blue ribbon in which you must provide, and they were very accommodating, and letting me know what works and what didn't. 

Just make sure that you do return their cake stand or you wont get your deposit back. This place is great to get their cakes!  Again if I ever was in the neighborhood I would buy my birthday cakes here, and my pastries for the family, the only thing is no parking and its in the middle the the busiest street in  Chinatown.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Egg tarts are delicious! We had to preorder ours since they were sold out for the time being. Had to wait 30 mins to get our dozen egg tarts. They are definitely larger than the typical ones, but they have a lot of custard in them. Custard is nice and soft while the crust is flaky and crispy. It is a little oily though, probably from all the butter in it, but they're delicious both right out of the oven or even overnight! At 80 cents a pop, the price really can't be beat. 

We also got some pork sung onion buns which were delicious. The bread is super soft (even the next day!!) which was quite surprising for me because most of the time bread hardens a bit. Not theirs! It's still super soft and doughy. I wish I got to try their durian buns, but I didn't see them until after it was too late..boo :(. The prices here are pretty cheap too. Staff is nice. Cash only. Not much seating, more of a take out place. Def will be coming back here next time I'm in Chinatown.
author: Susan M.

description: 5 Stars for the baked Pork Buns!! We live in the mid Peninsula and come here when we can - Strictly Pork Buns.  They are perfectly baked, doughy in the middle with just the right  (not too sweet) bbq pork on the inside. Hands down best pork bun I've ever had, and I've eaten many in my life! =) They are .90c and they are put in a pink box tied with pink twine.  Very cute! This is Chinatown. Don't expect customer service. Also, keep your elbows out and the line tight, because you will get Hip-Checked and cut in front of by an unsuspected OG here. Enjoy!!!
author: Teresa S.

description: This is the place the old man from the other bakery brought me to. The 蛋挞 was super tasty and even kept well in the fridge for a few days. The people inside told me that this is the place to get the egg tart if you want a good one. It was so reasonably priced as well. The workers were very friendly and kind during my time there.
author: Jake A.

description: Very convenient and inexpensive!  We got a coconut bun for $0.80 and an egg tart for $0.90.  This beats the prices in Southern California!  The place has plenty of seating and I am glad we found this place.  We had a good experience here with the friendly staff, so we are thankful.  We were also very hungry from all the exploring :)
author: Loretta C.

description:
I am in my late 50s' still working with multilingual language skills, English, Cantonese, Mandarin and Vietnamese.

Approximately 7:05am this morning, there were barely any customers inside the bakery. To start with , I requested to use the restroom due to my urgency. An employee in her late 50s' refused to allow me to use it and told me to walk for a few blocks for it although I told her that I was here to order some pastries.

Despite of it, I stayed there without leaving ( I would normally have under such situation). Because I wanted to keep my promise to my resigning colleague and the rest of others to buy Chinese pastries to bring back to my work place on time as a way to say " Good bye " and wished her the best, I decided to stay to make an order of three boxes, ten each separately.

Very disappointedly, the receiving order services I was provided from two female employees , one in her early 40s' in black clothes, and the other one in her late 50s' who are both Taishanese speaking, a Chinese dialect, were really bad. Their customer service attitudes to me was totally unacceptable due to their arrogance. I felt like that they did not want my business. 

Out of disappointment, dissatisfaction, and unhappiness, before I left the store, I said to the younger employee who is possibly the owner, " I have never seen a Taishanese person whom I know from my work location as mean as you to a customer". In her arrogant response to me, she said, " Get out here " although I was her customer and spent twenty dollars at her bakery store. She treated me as such. I will not definitely go back there . 

I hope that there must be some kind of training of customer services provided to arrogant employees and owners in this area. It has happened to me and probably to others and can happen to possible future visitors in this area.
author: Frank N.

description:
Coconut bread was the bomb!!!! 
And super cheap only .40c each. Busy little bakery but worth it. 

Can't wait to return!
author: Fatima A.

description:
Hot damn this place is good! They have a lovely selection of both sweet and savory buns depending on if you're looking for a light meal or a dessert! They're not as Americanized in terms of flavors as Sheng Kee so many of them hail to the Chinese roots, but there are a few surprises here and there...

The staff speaks decent English and everything is well-labeled there with the name and the price!

For example:
Meals: hot dog bun, and I highly recommend the $0.90 chicken cheese bun (chicken patty with tomato sauce and cheese) which is a far better value than the McChickens nowadays. Yes, they do have a substantial amount of meat in them to keep you full. 
Snacks: all of the savory buns that aren't as filling: pork sung ("furry shredded pork") bun, green onion bun
Desserts: cheese bread (a mini mini loaf with a whipped cream cheese filling), custard bun, Mexican bun, buttercream, raisin, etc etc

Expect to get pushed and shoved and be assertive in taking your turn, but the line moves quickly.
author: Brittany L.

description:
We ordered a quarter sheet birthday cake for our son's 6th birthday.  He picked the spongebob design. We were all impressed when we received the cake. It was so cute! Nice bright colors and super cute cake decorating. They used canned fruits for the cake but the cream and the cake were so fresh. 
The cake toppers are not only for decorating. They are launchers the child can play them as toys.
author: Ashley YH C.

description: This place is great. They are known for their 蛋挞 (egg tarts), which have the flaky crust. I also recommend their 菠萝包 (pineapple bun) and their 拿破仑 (Napoleon biscuit), the latter of which has this meringue-ish layer that's different from a lot of other Napoleons I've eaten. They're super cheap, too--90¢ for a big fluffy pineapple bun.
author: W. W.

description:
Pretty nice egg tarts - flakey crispy pastry, eggy custard. Maybe not quite as good / buttery as GGB but pretty good still. Plus no lines and better pricing.

80¢ an egg tart, best deal in chinatown, cash only
author: Jean K.

description:
Ugh! Don't make the mooncake pastries here...

I tried the "pig cookie" and it was disgusting!
There was no filling and the the flour was stale and bad....be careful!

Egg tarts have gone down in quality.  They used to be my alternative to Golden Gate Bakery. Not anymore....
author: David W.

description:
Their egg tarts tastes sooo much better than the famous Golden Gate Bakery!

I'm not a fan of Chinese cakes but these cakes are cheap for the office.
author: Alice X.

description:
When golden gate bakery is closed, I come here. 

If that isn't reason enough to come, they have baked custard buns that are gigantic and actually filled with custard and not air, for under a freaking dollar people. Stop reading this and go already!!!
author: Irene C.

description:
I ordered egg tart. It is a delicious choice. The egg tart is moderate warm and you can fill the softness of the egg at the bite. The taste of egg and cream linger in mouth all the way to the end and also a good custard consistency. The crispy layers of the flaky crust added more texture. 

Pineapple bun with red bean is also recommended, I love the top crust - not so sweet but crunchy and tasty.

The service is not so organized though. There is no waiting line so to speak. You need to seize the staff to order so they start pay attention to you.
author: Yixi F.

description:
There might not be long lines out the door like another popular Chinese bakery, but Napoleon is often packed with customers clamoring to order delicious buns.

Feeling adventurous? Get the durian bun! I was most excited for this at Napoleon's since it's rather rare to find. If you've never tasted or heard of this infamous fruit, don't miss out on trying it at Napoleon's. My boyfriend loves durian, so he'll describe it as tasty and sweet. I, on the other hand, consider it akin to onions in smell and taste. Be sure to ask for the durian bun to be packaged separately from any other items you order to avoid contaminating other foods with durian's pungent smell and taste.

The pineapple buns here are average. The bun itself is big and fluffy, but the sweet crust topping was lacking. This layer was thinner than that of pineapple buns elsewhere, so it was minimally sweet.

Egg tarts here are also average. The filling of egg tarts are usually lightly sweetened, and this one from Napoleon was especially light. Some might find it almost too bland for their tastes, but the custard's consistency was right and the crust was flaky.

The interior is a narrow space with just three small tables and chairs. My boyfriend and I were able to grab a table and two chairs, but it's definitely more of a grab and go place.

If you're looking for a cheap meal or snack, skip the lines elsewhere and enjoy the buns here!
author: Tanya A.

description:
Let the war begin!  Dan tat (custard tarts) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=ss7hGKO76tDF0v0_LbxHeg) is the subject of the great debate in Chinatown these days.  The king resides on Grant Avenue at Golden Gate Bakery.  The only true way to settle the duel is a side by side taste test... minor problem:  GG is closed half of the year, or so it seems. 
Rumor, a friend's cousin, reliability unconfirmed, recently heard that GG's baker now runs Napoleon's kitchen.  This piqued my curiosity so, on a recent Sunday, I picked up a six pack of custard tarts for the family.  When I got home, I immediately noticed a huge difference as they were cold.  Not refrigerator cold, mind you, but it certainly was not warm and toasty like GG's.  Here alone, the sense of smell being neutralized when cold, Napoleon is a notch below.
My friend said the trick is to pop them in the toaster oven and warm them to a flaky crispy texture.  Sadly, when your tummy grumbles, there's no time for that.
Came back to pick up a ham & egg bun, but they were out; instead, I got a ham and tomato bun (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=ffrVxzi3d3nySEcNJmKMqQ) which was interesting but can do without the mayo.  I also picked up some Gai Mei Bao (Chicken tail bun) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), which does not contain any chicken in it... so, don't be afraid.  Like the coconut filling, but sadly it wasn't spread evenly and was mostly on one side of the bread.
There are two tables at the window for dine-in, but their mostly occupied by regular customers which include retirees and plumbers (you know who you are).
Overall, it's disappointing that their offering were mostly cold as nothing beats fresh bake.  For me, it's just okay here.
author: Mike C.

description: Came here to try some egg tarts and hot dog buns.  Prices are cheap, only 80 cents each.  The employees aren't super friendly but whatevers.  The food was pretty good.  I did not like the egg tart though.  It was literally falling apart and was soft and soggy.  Not even average.  The hot dog buns are pretty good though.  This is a cash only place.
author: Betty H.

description: They have a bun with a whole chicken nugget patty in the middle!!! And it's topped with cheese and a ketchup sauce! Probably one of the best things ever invented
author: Linz C.

description: First time tried a durian bun and egg tart. Good to try a durian bun at least once. In this case,"Curiosity did not kill the cat." LOL I am still alive, but durian does stink. I like the egg custard. It was well balanced with the custard and the crust. I would come back to try other buns and egg tarts.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Egg custard is definitely one of the best in China town. Coconut mini cake are really good too. Will try other items on the menu later.
author: mui d.

description: I love their buns, pastries and cakes! My favorite are the Mexican buns, ham and egg, and Ham and pork, yum! Very affordable, less than $1 per bun. Their egg tarts are really good and affordable as well! I think 70 cents for an egg tart compared to $1 elsewhere. Their lemon cake roll is really good too! And their birthday cakes with fruit are not too sweet and heavy - my family always order cakes from them for special occasions. I come here often and I would definitely recommend this place for cakes, pastries and buns. :)
author: Bailey L.

description:
Got a craving for durian buns?  They've got them here!

My love for all things durian brought me here to this dingy Chinese bakery located in the middle of SF Chinatown.  Came in late Saturday afternoon expecting a huge crowd, but to our surprise there was none.  So, we were able to get a good look at all the different kinds of buns they offered: taro, red bean, custards, raisins, and of course, durian buns!  Ended up packing home 1/2 dozen durian buns and a dozen egg tarts for a little over $14.xx!  Talk about frugal guilty pleasures :)

The buns themselves were pretty yummy.  The bread was soft and sweet and the durian filling tasted very potent (just wished there was more of it), closer to the taste of the actual fruit itself of which I love the best.

Overall, It is a slightly stinky pastry that's worth trying and I will be back for more of their durian bao(s).

Cash only! :)
author: Veronica C.

description:
Cash only.

I came here at 4pm to order some pastries for a snack and ended up getting two coconut raisin breads and one pork bun. Neither pastries were the best I've ever had, but at $.80, I can't complain at all. The coconut raisin pastry had enough toppings to cover the entire length of the bread, and while the pork bun was a bit cold (expected), it had a decent amount of filling inside.
author: Austin W.

description: I totally love this Super Napoleon Bakery of the San Francisco Chinatown  Area and other than Double AA Bakery... Super Napoleon Bakery is now considered as my second go to bakery for a quick bite to go!!! And my most favorite thing that... I really like eating the most from the Super Napoleon Bakery would be the Cheese Chicken Bun!!! But there is just one thing that... I can't stand the most is when this Super Napoleon Bakery gets really packed with lots aggressive customers!!! I would have to wait a while in line as I buy my most favorite Cheese Chicken Bun as a my quick bite on the go!!! And my advice to all of you yelpers out there... Don't be surprised when this Super Napoleon Bakery gets really super packed most of times!!!
author: William B.

description:
Out of everything for my wedding, our wedding cake was the BEST deal. Honestly the BEST bang for your buck. Three tier cake, three layers, with delivery for UNDER $280. Serves 130 people. Oh yea. And if you return the cake holder, you can get $35 back. 

Ordering was easy. Just walk in, show them photos of what you want. How many levels.  What date, where to deliver and the flavors you want.  Paid upfront. 

Did I mention the cake was DELICIOUS?! I had guests come up to say it was the best wedding cake they've ever had. Who doesn't like mango cake? You don't? Okay, how about strawberry? No? There's also chocolate. 

Yes, the cake isn't made by super fancy artists, but it worked. We cared more about the taste and the $ more than if it looked like it was straight from Martha Stewart or something. Honestly, I don't believe it's worth paying more than $300 for a wedding cake. Looking at other bakeries, they started at $500. Yes, we could always have gone with the cupcake route, but we wanted cake, and a cake from an Asian bakery since they're usually lighter, fluffier and just better than others. 

Only thing is, it is best if you can speak Cantonese fluently. If you can't, bring a translator.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I have this kind of cake all through my childhood. So it reminds me of my childhood. It is Light and yummy (not too sweet). Sometime, you will get frustrated about their rude service, but I will still get cake from here.
author: Ivy Z.

description:
Stopped by to get an egg tart / egg custard. 
It certainly helps to know how to speak chinese if you want to get an order in. Also, BE ASSERTIVE. the line starts in 10 different places and people are yelling in chinese everywhere. But once you fight through the crowd and emerge victoriously with your egg tart... it sure does taste good. 

It was delicious, but not the best i've ever had.
The egg filling was creamy, but the outside crust was a little dry for me.

I also got the durian bread! not as smelly as the actual durian fruit but it was delicious and interesting. 

I would def recommend this to people who like egg tarts and judge for themselves!
author: Yong K.

description: Never really liked the attitude of theirs workers, always kind of rude and talks to you like they want to to disappear, but their food is good so what ever.
author: Amy H.

description:
There is nothing more adorable and nostalgic than the scene of a modest, bustling bakery with lots of loud Chinese yelling and a crowd of elderly folks enjoying their time at the local bakery of SF Chinatown.

True, there is something undeniably authentic about hole-in-the-wall Chinese bakeries, but for better or worse 85 c has proven that it is possible to create legitimate Chinese pastries with quality.

Prices are unbelievably low for the huge buns and they have a lot of options, but I've found that their bread tends to be bland.  I would strongly recommend the egg tarts instead--not only can you obtain delicious egg tarts without having to put up with the craziness at Golden Gate Bakery; if you come on a busy weekend morning you may be able to catch one straight out of the oven.  The layered, flaky pastry shell and soft custard filling is definitely worth the adventure of a walk through Chinatown, which is perhaps in itself a factor contributing to the authenticity experience.
author: Edna C.

description:
Egg tarts/custards. There's definitely a huge competition for who's the best dan tat maker in the Bay Area. I'll admit that most folks, including myself, have a major preference toward Golden Gate Bakery (also made famous by the 7x7 eats list), but having just tried one of these today I'll also admit that Napoleon's egg custards kinda blew me away. You can't necessarily tell by appearance, but these not-so-little suckers for 70 cents a piece were pretty fantastic. I don't have a side-by-side, but I can tell you that the crust at first taste seems better than GGB's. If you prefer an egg-ier custard, you'll probably like Napoleon's more, and if you like a more watered-down, lighter custard you'll say GGB's is better.

This place earns high marks for a very solid dan tat that (for the price point and no wait time) is tied in place with Golden Gate Bakery. Next time I'll be sure to do a dan tat double fisting competition to determine the real winner!
author: Joanne Y.

description:
This is my back up bakery for egg tarts when I can't get Golden Gate Bakery. Their egg tarts crust are still nice and flaky and the egg part has the perfect balance of sweetness. Only $0.70 for egg tarts, you can basically get 2 for the price you pay at Golden Gate Bakery.

If you like durian, I highly recommend the durian buns. There are these crunchy nuggets on the top of the bun and inside has fresh creamy durian. You have to eat them fresh out of the oven. I thought they were good the first time my mom bought it home but after eating it fresh from the bakery it's not the same.
author: Ivy L.

description:
I came here to get a half dozen egg tarts and I was pleasantly surprised to find that I came at the same time that a fresh batch came out! The egg tarts were very hot and because of that, they tasted 10 times better than room temperature egg tarts. The size of the egg tarts is more on the larger end, and there was a large portion of custard in each tart relative to chain store bakery style egg tarts. There wasn't a line when I went in, but if there were one, the egg tarts are worth the wait.

The only issue is that the employee who was taking my order seemed to understand what I was saying, whether I was speaking in English or Mandarin, but would reply to me in Cantonese. Nope! I was brought up by Mandarin (and Taiwanese)- speaking parents; Cantonese wasn't going to cut it. She only spoke to me in English because she wanted to know if I had coins on me so she wouldn't have to give me coins in change. The next time I show up here, I think I'll want to learn some Cantonese, or just deal with some confusion speaking in English or Mandarin until I get those egg tarts in my hands.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
If Golden Gate Bakery wasn't closed, I would had never discovered this place.  I aimlessly walked into this place to order dan tats (egg tarts).  

OMGEEEE!  There was no rhyme or reason in this bakery.  The line to order was mad cow unorganized!!!  There were Chinese people standing in front of the pastry cabinet screaming out their orders to any breathing cashier!  This little Chinese lady stepped in front of me and ordered her pineapple buns before the cashier was even done with the last customer.  I got shafted by a few aggressive old ladies customers... Well, I won't have it!  I listened! I learned! I did not make eye contact!  I screamed out my order before the cashier was done giving out change... SUCCESS!!!!  I got my 3 dan tats and got the hell out of there.

The moment I stepped out, I devoured my dan tat.  It was fresh out of the oven and so good!  It's not Golden Gate bakery foodgasm good but very close to it.  Highly recommended if you want some tats.  At $0.75 each, its definitely worth eating.

NOTES: BE aggressive when ordering, otherwise, you'll feel stupid for standing so long with no service.  Eye contact doesn't work here!
author: Jenny T.

description: Good service from the old lady who answered my call!!! The line goes faster and less confuse than the location in Oakland, service was better than Oakland as well. The workers at Oakland are bitchy. This one is wayyyyyyyy better.
author: Jenn J.

description:
I'm on a mission to find good egg tarts.  Napoleon is okay for .90c.  Totally experienced the lady not wanting to serve me when I was the second person in line.  Another lady came in of Asian decent, and the clerk tried to serve her, clearly seeing I was there first.  The lady was so kind to say I came first, thanks!  Put in my order and the clerk slams my change on the counter not even looking at me.  Can we say RUDE!!!!!  Not even a crowd in there, so no need to be crazy.  I can't wait for Golden Gate Bakery to come back from vacation already.  

The egg tart was edible, nothing special.  I'm going to keep hunting around Chinatown during my breaks.
author: Michelle M.

description:
(Skip to the **** to read the juicy part!) This is for all the people planning your WEDDING!

Brides, hear me out!

I've previously written a review for them, 5 stars, but that's for their regular buns and what not. This one is for my wedding cake that they really DISAPPOINTED ME IN. 

So you can see that my cake is beautifully made via the pictures I made and that I'm not making all this up, to own this review I even have a picture of me with the cake.

When I placed this order I specifically said that I wanted their regular fruit cake, the one that tastes like a plain/vanilla sponge cake with fresh fruit fillings. I made it very clear. 5 tiers, square cake, every single layer the exact same taste. They assured me it would, they even told me their owner would be making the cake for me, and blah blah blah. 

*******The day of the wedding came around, the cake looked beautiful. Then I realized when it was served, about 6 of my tables hadn't finished their cake, or took a bite and left it there. Then one of my guests came up to me and told me that their cake went bad, tasted funny, and then a  couple of more people did. Turns out my 3rd and 4th tier had a lot of coconut extract in the cake, not the regular vanilla. When I went back to the bakery to talk to them about to get some money back they told me, "Oh, we added it because our OTHER GUESTS said it tasted good..." And I was like well I'm not that guest, I didn't like it, MY GUESTS thought that the cake had went bad. They sent me away without any of my money back. So you can understand my frustration right? 

On another note, it didn't bother me at first but since I'm already dissatisfied with what happen I'll also complain about another thing about my cake they decided to do. 

I handed them a picture, a very large, clear picture of what design I wanted on the tiers. It was 2 alternating patterns. They once again said they understood and will definitely do it for me, even wrote it down. Not only was it NOT the DESIGN I wanted, they also made it the same on every singly layer. So yeah...

******Bottom line? They're good.. but I suggest you making them write it down on paper that if they mess up, that they need to compensate you correctly. Would I recommend them? ONLY if you are short on cash, even then it was still an EXPENSIVE, CASH ONLY place.
author: Terinna R.

description:
I remember when my parents used to go to Chinatown
and come back with 3 pink boxes
full of goodies from Napoleon.
Dan tat, bo lo bao, gai mei bao galore.
("All fo under twenty dolla!" said my mom.)
And that would be my breakfast + lunch for a week.
No wonder I was so fat.... (-.-)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
This review is long overdue from me: Mmm not the most perfect bakery that you see in Texas or other parts of the Bay Area but this place is the best when it comes to bread. Do not get the large cakes unless you are secure with what you buy. I like all the bread that they make here it is affordable and can last until you finish everything in the box. Most bread and small item are under $1.75 which is good because for a person who rarely takes breaks in or visits Chinatown this is the place to go. It is easy to remember where it is and it isn't far if you take the notorious #30 or just about any MUNI bus. It would be great if it was in San Jose too but you can't beat quality. If you are getting a large cake for a special occasion go somewhere else because the cake has been in the selling glasses for IDK how many weeks but the important thing is you should really come here a few times. This one female employee even recognizes my mom or me when we come. Also be quick because the bread and small items sell quick!
Drawbacks: they take cash only so be sure to have it in hand when ordering.
author: Michael W.

description: It is located in China town. A friend highly recommended the shop. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. They offer many kinds of bread and cakes. We ordered egg tarts. I love them so much.
author: Nancy S.

description:
We really needed a snack and if you know me that means I needed an egg tart. We checked out some places we had been before in this part of Chinatown and the place that always seems to be on vacation despite its great reviews was indeed on vacation again. We have never found it open though clearly other people are reviewing it. 

Anyway, we saw a line of locals here so we thought we should try it. The selection was not large, especially so far after noon but we tried a few things and truthfully, I could not have gotten a better egg tart. Warm, fresh and moist and the crust was nicely browned. The BBQ pork buns could have had a little more filling but the meat was tender and tasty. The staff was friendly and did speak English so were were able to get  exactly what we wanted. 

They even had  two tables for those who were not just taking food home and needed to sit and snack. That was nice because we were exhausted.
author: Sara M.

description: Avg pork buns (could use more meat and less fat but the bread is fine), but the egg tarts are pretty good here! 4 star tarts.
author: Linus W.

description:
This was another one of the bakeries that I visited for my egg custard showdown.  We were a little less impressed as compared to some other ones we sampled today.  We agreed that the custard had a nice, creamy consistency - probably the best texture of the lot - but it was curiously lacking in flavor.  The crust was a little on the mushy/crumbly side.

We also tried one of their coconut buns.  Light, soft, with a generous amount of sweet ground coconut in the middle.  I was tempted to get one of their BBQ pork buns but I was starting to get overloaded with baked goods.
author: Lee L.

description:
Great place for bao (chinese term for bread/buns)

I come here cause its a good buddy of mine's favorite bread place.  I agree that everything tastes as good as it looks.  It'll range from a mini crowd to nobody there so its sort of a lottery of what you run into.  That said, the bread selection is delicious and even the uncle cookies (lo gong bang) is a personal favorite of mine.  The only reason why I don't come here often is cause it is Chinatown and you can get bao for HALF the price of what this place charges.  Granted half the price of something can be $.70 to $.35 but the Asian inside me says if i go somewhere else I can buy 1 get 1 free and we all know asians (me) jump at all things free.
author: Samuel Y.

description: For the past few years my Grandma has been buying us durian cakes from Napoleon for our birthday's. And I absolutely LOVE it. Durian is one of my favorite fruits- the smell doesn't get to me I think it actually smells good haha. Their durian cakes are filled with chunky durian pieces and are very creamy! Too bad they don't sell them here in LA where I live now. Whenever I'm back home and see a cake in the fridge, I know its from Napoleon. YUMMMMMM.
author: Tommy L.

description:
The absolute best eggs custards in Chinatown. 

I just ran a 5k this morning and decided to stop by and get myself 5 egg custards
author: Mia F.

description: Been coming here ever since I was a child. Everytime I walk in, I go straight to the back where they are pulling out racks upon racks of freshly baked egg custards. It can be a bit chaotic, as nearly everyone is trying to get an order of these in. I have consumed an excessive amount of egg custards throughout the years and always find myself coming back here to get my fix for egg custards regardless of craziness. Besides the egg custards, the coconut buns are also delicious.
author: Christine G.

description:
My gf insisted that we stop here while in Chinatown.  From the looks of it, a pretty typical Chinese bakery, of which there are several around in the area (somewhat obviously).  As are a lot of places in SF, this place is very small and it can be somewhat difficult to get in and out.

Upon entering, to your left you will see the glass case full of the various types of buns/pastries/snacks/etc.  All the usual suspects appear.  We ordered a hot dog bun, scallion bun, and fresh-out-of-the-oven egg custard tart.  Both of the buns were pretty standard really, both in flavor, size and cost.  My gf really likes the egg custard tart...I thought it was just okay.  This one errs towards a very eggy flavor, as opposed to the slightly sweeter version I'm used to and prefer.  Good flaky crust though.

This place is just fine as a Chinese bakery goes.  No better or worse than any other I've ever been to.  I would stop here again.
author: Brent T.

description:
What's up with the service here? The lady behind the counter who took my order seemed nice at first and when she told me the total, ($1.80) I handed her $2. My change should be 20 cents. She handed me two nickels and I looked at her, I told her the change is wrong and she said no. I asked her how much was the total again and then she changed the total to $1.90. I asked her why would two of the same items that cost 0.90 = $1.90. It should be $1.90. She claimed that she had given me back 20 cents and made me look like the biggest penny pincher in front of everyone and disregarded my request for correct change. I used to come here as a kid and loved it here and now, not so much. 

Firstly, I work in the food service industry so I'm familiar with penny pinchers. Secondly, it's the principle (hope I used the right principle) that she should take responsibility to correct her mistakes. I wouldn't have even cared so much about this incident if it was for me telling my uncle what had happened and he said the same thing happened to him years ago. He handed a lady behind the counter a $10 bill and had given him change as if he had paid with a $5 bill. They argued and she wouldn't budge to give him back the change. 

I can't believe I'm wasting my time on them but I refuse to be cheated for my money because I work hard for it and I don't appreciate businesses and (owners) taking advantage of their employees or customers for pennies. It makes them look pitiful and untrustworthy. Per usual, I look non-Chinese so when I shop in Chinatown, more than likely cashiers assume I only understand English but nonetheless, I speak Cantonese and English fluently. 

The items I purchased tasted similar as it did when I was younger but the fillings to bread ratio has been lessened and a bit drier with air pockets hidden. They have plenty of business at this bakery and I'm happy for the people who do not get cheated by the owners. Fortunately, there is a new bakery in town, Fancy Wheat Field Bakery where the old Victoria's Bakery used to be located. Good luck to not losing business, Napoleon.
author: Margherita S.

description: Price was so low for such a good durian bun. They use real durian so you can still taste the durian flesh. The bun itself was soft and sweet. They should put more durian inside the bun since it looks they only fill in the middle part of the bun. Will try for the other bun as well.
author: Valentine W.

description:
After an entire-day long adventure of hiking and exploring, my friend insisted that we stopped by Napoleon to pick up some pastries for an event she was going to the next day.  Even though it was 6pm and most of the baked goods were sold out, there were still quite a bit of items left on the rack, to select from.  Various buns, big and small, and all for a great price! Everything was roughly 5 buns for $1.20.  How can you go wrong with that?!?!

If only we were there earlier to get more variety...but that's not their fault.  It was just nice to find a place that was open late and still had some things left on their shelves. :)
author: Audrey C.

description:
The ham and egg buns are the best. They make the best pastries in Chinatown. This place can be crowded and busy at certain times, but every pastry items there are very appropriately priced.

3/29/2014:
Their Green Tea and Red Bean Bun is delicious

If you do want to be able to get the pastry items you want, then coming in before 9 am or 10 am is the best decision to make.

The staff members here are very friendly, good food and good service.
author: Bennett W.

description: We just came in to redeem our $10 coupon, so we bought a variety of things. It's a really small shop that is very crowded. The food is okay. Very inexpensive.
author: Steph Q.

description:
Note: review on egg tarts only

I think this is my second fave place to buy egg tarts ($0.70/tart). Comparing these with AA and VIP, I feel the egg tarts at Napoleon have more egg custard than dough, especially at the bottom. Also, the texture of the egg custard seems more mushy than the others, although the custard is very light.

You could say this is your best bet for "best bang for your buck."
author: Janel Y.

description:
Napoleon S.F. is so unlike  napolean oaktown. no lines here. no dimsum (didn't see) no cheap 3fer buns.  no inferior stuff either. just midrange good eats at a modest price.

eats:
-crispy pork crisps(.90)
taste like king' s hawaiian bread with the "pork sung" topping taiwanese typically use for their jook(porridge) a little bit of "cream" is under the pork crisps. 
*very unique and tasty
-baked bbq bun (..80)
nothing spectacular but nicely baked bun with bits of bbq pork bits within. not a lot of filling.

crumbs:
-not cheap but good stuff here
-usually no waiting
-many associates to serve patrons
-cash only
author: Victor G.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite Chinese bakeries in Chinatown. Looks are definitely deceiving at Super Napolean. The pastries look like there is much to be desired.

The line, or the lack thereof is challenging...even for those that speak their language. The line concept is more of a "push-your-way-to-the-front-of-the-line-and-get-the-employee's-attention."

Despite the semi-chaotic environment, do definitely do some mental math before paying. The employees sometimes have a way of magically inflating the bill...even though if it's a 10-20 cents...

Some of my favorite pastries include the baked BBQ pork bun, Sausage scallion bun, curry beef bun, and tuna bun. The baked egg tarts are definitely tasty for $0.70. Comparable with Golden Gate, at a fraction of the price, line, and attitude.
author: Derek S.

description: Egg tarts .80 just as good as over rated+priced ggb. They also have durian bao too.  Yummy.
author: S F.

description: MY FAVORITE FAVORITE!! I don't care if its fattening or whatever, it's worth it! My gosh....everyone in my family and even my boyfriend, love the durian bun!!! This is the only place that I found durian buns. I would buy a lot plus some other buns. I wish I can get more next time! I recommend it here!
author: Apple S.

description:
My friend was raving about this place after I mentioned my love for Asian baked goods. I was a bit disappointed that they had ran out of the taro bun, so I settled for the egg custard. It was ONLY 80 CENTS, suchhhh a steal. If I wasn't stuffed from lunch, I woulda stocked up and eaten them for the rest of the day!

It was delicious! The bun looks a lot heavier and filling than it actually is, which in my case was a good thing. They're pretty big, but you'll find that most of contents is air, lol. The bun itself is incredibly moist, and has a subtle sweetness to it. But what really makes the bun is the egg custard filling. It's got the perfect consistency.

I'm definitely coming back here every time I visit SF :D.
author: Christina N.

description:
I have been coming here since I was a kid! This place never fails to disappoint me. Their dan tats (egg tars) is definitely comparable to that of Golden Gate Bakery's and probably is only half the price! They have a variety of bread and buns to choose from! My favorites are probably their cream bun, pineapple bun, hot dog bun, corn bun, and sponge cake!

They also sell cake rolls (lemon, vanilla, chocolate, etc.) and full/slice of cakes! Their cakes are pretty popular for special events such as birthdays! Definitely not overly sweet like the American cakes that you get from Costco! You can request for a small special message to be written on the cake!

There is no line whatsoever. People are pretty aggressive in getting their breads and buns so do not stand back and wait for your turn because that would probably mean standing there for a good two hours or so before even getting to you! I would suggest you bringing a friend that can speak Chinese to go with you if you can not speak Chinese. It will definitely be an advantage! Trust me. Don't forget to yell what you want to the ladies working behind the counter!

Parking is almost impossible around here unless you're super super lucky! You will save yourself some time if you park two or three streets away from Chinatown and walk there instead.

CASH ONLY. (Tip: Always carry cash when you go to Chinatown)
author: Shanna C.

description:
The only reason I go to Napoleon is because their prices are lower than other bakeries (AA, Golden Gate).  But you get what you pay for.  Service is terrible, and the baked goods are average.

If you don't speak Chinese, it's hard to get service when it's crowded.  I used to live a few blocks away, so have been to Napoleon at least 30 times.  The last time, I stood patiently waiting to be helped, and other customers would come in, scream out their order in Cantonese, and receive it immediately.  After 10 minutes, I left empty-handed.
author: Jen K.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery likes to go on "vacation" sometimes, so when you have that egg tart craving, you end up having to search around for the next best place. Napoleon just happened to be that for me. 

I walked in as the ladies at the back of the store were unloading trays of egg tarts. And when I say trays, I mean HUGE trays, and several of them. Unsurprisingly, things here are very disorganized. No line, just Chinese ladies screaming at each other to get what they want. I swear they went through at least a tray of egg tarts for people randomly going in front of me before I was helped. Not sure if they already ordered and paid or if I was just the awkward white guy who they didn't want to serve. Lesson learned, be more aggressive!

I left with six steaming hot, creamy, flaky egg tarts. That dan tat just melts so perfectly in your mouth, it feels like you're floating on a cloud. A cloud of fluffy, creamy, egg filling. I still haven't had a chance to try Golden Gate, but I doubt the difference is that stark.
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
I bought 3 items from here to try:
1. Egg tarts, great buy for 80 cents each and I liked their tarts much better after a home taste test comparing their tarts to ones from AA bakery across the street. Their crust tasted more buttery and the center filling was good.
2. Didn't like the curry beef pastry.  It was really puffy but bland tasting. The filling was good but not enough beef.
3.  Didn't like the pastry puff square either, one of my favorite items from childhood.  Similiar to a rice krispy square.  Theirs was rather hard, didn't have enough coconut in it and not chewy enough.  
They have a much more limited menu compared to AA Bakery. I did see seniors in their shopping for their other baked buns and baked goods as their prices are much more reasonable.  For me, I'd come back for their egg tarts.  Golden Gate Bakery was closed for 2 days when we walked by today so we had to come here for the egg tarts.
author: Ry T.

description:
It was a drive-by.

Maybe not, but on a beautiful Thursday morning, I decided to go on dim-sum hopping, and after viewing Napoleon Bakery's Yelp reviews, I knew I had to try the egg tarts.

It's slightly sweeter than most, and it's got more "egg" taste to it.  The outer crust is fluffy, and it can tend to fall apart quite quickly.  

Again, it's not a place you should go out of your way for, but if you're in SF Chinatown already, you can't go wrong with the egg tarts here.
author: Sam L.

description:
what i ordered... egg tart

tasty!.... the only two difference i found against my benchmark at GGB
1) crust was a millimeter or two thicker
2) at half the price

... this is now THE place to go to for egg tart for locals in SF, you can hardly see or hear any yuppies and out of towners at this place. (hopefully they don't 'follow' me :) )

ambiance... so-so (cluttered)
service... so-so (lost in translation and quick)
cost... $- (so inexpensive)
author: Gors P.

description: Loved the durian bun, I wish I had tried the the coconut and custard buns I got, not enough time or stomach space ...
author: Robert C.

description:
When it's busy, prepare yourself to be aggressive and pushy if you don't want to be overlooked. No lines, just push your way to the front!

I love the paper-wrapped sponge cake. 70 cents for small or $1.00 for large. Yum. Two small tables inside. I bought a large sponge cake, and then started eating the dim sum I bought at Good Mong Kok next door before starting in on the cake. :)
author: Liv K.

description:
My parents have been bribing me with goodies from Napoleon Super Bakery since I was 6 years old. In order to yank me out of bed on a Saturday morning to attend Chinese school, I require a warm hot dog bun. Over the years, as my taste buds develop, I learned to appreciate other types of bake goods. For example, egg tarts, durian buns, and green tea buns. 

Napoleon makes the best egg tarts in the city. Here, the egg tarts have a flaky crust that houses a creamy and smooth egg filling. For credibility reasons, I am egg tart enthusiastic, in which I have had egg tarts throughout the city, from Golden Gate Bakery to Sunset Bakery. 

Additionally, Napoleon has an unique bun selection, from the traditional buns to their own inventions. Napoleon is the only bakery in the city that bakes durian buns and green tea buns. When these buns are piping hot, their aroma can fill a room with buttery delight. The buns are gigantic, fluffy, and soft. The fillings are slightly sweet and a creamy delight. These buns are even delicious when reheated in the microwave. 

In conclusion, Napoleon is probably the second most popular bakery in Chinatown. Although there is a line to fight for your goodies, the line is a mere short 5 minute wait. Most patrons have done their research and know what to order. I always leave Napoleon happy and satisfied; it is definitely worth the fight.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
My craving for their durian buns took me to this little shop in Chinatown, the sign outside is faded but the fresh bakery smell is unmistakeable as you approach the place on Stockton.

For the newbs, you HAVE to get those mature(?) ladies' attention if you want your baked goodies without being overlooked. I locked eyes instantly with one as time stood still while my heart begins to race faster and faster, sweat is now gathering on the surface of my palms and I can barely utter the right words...

"One durian bun, please?"

The exchange was brief but heartfelt. I flashed a smirk and departed with my lone durian bun - it was warm and fulfilling as I inhaled it on my way back to the office. It's a great day to be alive indeed. 

I'll be back for the egg tarts next time.
author: Roy H.

description:
Poor Cleanness!! Just found a mosquito in the middle of the cake, I am not sure If I ate its legs!  And it is huge, about 2 cm for the body. Just file complain to the health inspection.  

Damn, I have been feeding the same kind of cake to my baby since she turns 1!  I am still digging out my throat try to get as much as out !! please see the pictures! No way I can fake it.
author: YI W.

description: It gets a 3 star because everything is pretty inexpensive.  I took the time to write this review bc I think the quality of the items is not up to the standards of some of the other nearby bakeries.  I tried the cocktail bun and the coconut raisin bread.  I LOVE cocktail buns, and while theirs was warm, and the bread was good, the filling was essentially butter with a little coconut in it.  So if you like butter, you might love them.  The coconut raisin bread looked amazing, but I actually stopped eating bc the flavor just wasn't there, and the bread was a bit dry (perhaps bc it was cold?).  Anyway it's an authentic chinatown place with low prices, and it's popular, so others seem to like it, but I wouldn't go there again given the other nearby options.
author: L C.

description:
This place has been a big disappointment for me and my family.  Although expensive, they used to have really good Durian breads.  Unfortunately when we bought it yesterday, the breads barely have any Durian in there anymore... I ate through half the bread to realize that there's a nickle size amount of Durian.  They're cheaping out and still charging us the same cost $1.29 each bread.  Wow really??!!  Can't get worse than that?  I think not!  My dad tried to use the restroom to pee, grabbed a paper, and they started complaining about how much a paper cost like $0.01 cent or whatever .  Come on man... can they get any cheaper than that?  MY dad ended up paying back the cent which they accepted.  Wow.. Don't own a buisness if you're going to be so cheap, don't even bother providing paper.  

My idea is this... if they cheap out customers with paper, I highly doubt that their own workers would wash their hands from trying to SAVE A FEW CENTS OF PAPER!  Or , they would dry their hands over and over on this dirty rag....  (EW.. I ate their food!!!!!!)  WE ARE NOT COMING HERE EVER AGAIN!!!! EVER.. THEY JUST LOST A FAMILY OF BUSINESS THAT USUALLY SPENDS A LOT HERE.  Too bad so sad.  I'd give no stars if I could ...

Maybe  THEY NEED a sign in the bathroom that says "DON'T USE OUR PAPER, NEED TO DRY YOUR HANDS?  WIPE IT ON YOUR CLOTHES"
author: Juila L.

description:
Napoleon Super is one of the popular bakeries in Chinatown that sells Hong Kong style bakery items as well as some cakes and cream-filled cake rolls.  They do have an extensive selection of buns, plain to ones with fillings such as custard, cream, durian, red bean and coconut.  Other selections include egg tarts, almond cookies, paper wrapped sponge cakes, sponge cupcakes, rice puffs and melon cakes.  

Their bakery items are very good and compared to many of their competitors, the prices are very reasonable.  I usually get the raisin wheat rolls, my Mom's favorite, at 40 cents each and the large pineapple buns, a bun with a flaky, sweet topping, at 4 for $1.30.  Some bakeries sell the pineapple bun for about 75 cents each.

The only challenge here is that you'll have to deal with a crowd to put in your order.  You can't be timid here and just have to work your way up to the counter.  Then target a worker near you that is finishing up the transaction with another customer and start vocalizing your order.  Hopefully, she takes you as her next customer and takes your order.  Also, it's cash only and basically a take-out place since there is only three little tables there.
author: Al L.

description: Hands down, the best Asian bakery by far in Chinatown. The prices are UNBEATABLE for the quality and amount of goods you can get. A bun usually ranges around 60 to 80 cents. They have all kinds of fillings...pineapple custard bun, green tea bun with red bean, mexican bun, pork buns, and more! My favorite are the egg tarts. They are only 70 cents for a big, flaky, generous amount of egg filling. Cheaper than the ones at Golden Gate Bakery and no wait times. You must come visit when you're in Chinatown!
author: Elina L.

description:
after doing extensive research for some durian bday cake and glad this was the spot to have it. I live in sacramento to come all the way to sf china town and brought back this cake for my moms bday. the cake did not melt for two hrs In the car and wasnt deformed either. it was perfectly wrapped in a cute pink box. 

the cake was fluffy and moist and it was a three layer cake with 2 layers filled with durian in it and fresh silky smooth creme on the outside. the cake tasted amazing if ur a durian lover! it was not sweet at all like the american cakes u get. and the best thing about this cake it wad only 20 bucks for a 8 inch and 9 inchnis 3 dollars extra for 23 ....

over all I will be back for another durian bday cake for my duriam lovers friends and family.
author: Alex T.

description:
This location at 1049 Stockton Street is a bit larger in overall space and sells the same variety of specialty buns and other baked goods as its Clement Street location.

Because it is situated in Chinatown however you'll often find that the customers here are pushy and rude which by no means will impact my rating.  In fact, because of this I have found that the workers here are extremely patient.

We picked up my dad's birthday cake here recently, a sponge cake layered in real whipped cream with fresh strawberries, mandarin orange pieces, sweet honeydew and ripe cantaloupe.  It was very good.  The cake was very spongy and the cream was not very sweet.

I like the large squares of puff usually found on a covered tray on top of the pastry case.  These are deep fried puffs of dough held together by a sweet, sticky glaze then finished off with finely shaved coconut.  They're not quite as good as the puff sold at the Queen's Bakery in Chinatown Los Angeles, but for San Francisco these are mighty tasty.

The mango mousse cake and chocolate mousse cakes are good too but are not always available.  Sponge cake and a thin film of whipped cream hold up an enormous portion of lightly sweetened, smooth mousse that is finished with another layer of whipped cream.  The mango had a very light mango essence, but the chocolate one had mini chocolate chips throughout and of the two I thought it tasted better.  I have found other flavors of mousse cakes such as taro root and honeydew but have tried neither.  These are normally available as whole cakes, but occasionally you'll find them sold as slices.

If you don't mind shopping with the occasional rude, pushy person who will then stand there and give you the stare down when you push them back this is a nice Asian bakery to visit.  If that kind of adventure bothers you go ahead and travel out to their location on Clement Street.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I have never been able to make it here early enough to get the items that the other yelpers have recommended (such as their pineapple buns and egg tarts).  Each time that I have come, they were all sold out of those items.  However, they still had red bean buns and coconut buns.  

The prices are great (especially for the quality of the buns) and the food is delicious.  Whenever my father knows I'll be visiting him after being in the area,  (btw, for those of you have an American palate, my father is a blonde haired, blue-eyed Canadian and won't eat "the strange stuff") he asks that I "bring those buns with the red stuff inside and the yellow sugar sprinkly things on top."

(IF FOLLOWING MY "CHINATOWN FOODIE TOUR, be adventurous and try whatever looks interesting.  This place is super cheap but really good so stock up on items that you plan to bring home here.)
author: Linda H.

description: Very good cheesecake! It has an outer spongy layer and the middle is the very light tender and moist cheesecake. Very reasonably priced!!! Less than $2. Street parking. No frills bakery in Chinatown. Did not order the egg tart because it was not warn or piping hot.
author: Kitty D.

description:
I used to love this place because they have the best (whole) cakes. The cakes are always very light with fruits and have the best whipped cream frosting. I always got my cakes from here and it's always decently priced as well.

But today, I was in the neighborhood and since I'm going on vacation in a few days, I didn't feel like buying an entire cake so I opted for two slices to bring home. One was a chocolate/coffee slice and the other a cheesecake type slice.

They had three boxes of the cheesecake slices left and I'd pointed at the one in the glass closest to me, telling the Cantonese lady that I wanted the one up front and she ignored me and grabbed the one all the way in the back that didn't look nearly as fresh. I wasn't about to put up a fight with her so I thought, alright, whatever.

After I got home and tasted the cake I was thoroughly disappointed. The cheesecake was extremely dry, crumbly, and stiff. It honestly tasted like the slice had been sitting there for more than a week. 

I'm very disappointed in this bakery and after years of buying cakes from them I will never go back.
author: Tevina T.

description:
Eh, not a big fan. I don't think the breads and pastries here are worthy of the work it takes to purchase one. There's no line, so every one shoves their way to the front and shots out their orders. I'll pass 
the egg tarts here are definitely not comparable to golden gate bakery.
author: Connie M.

description:
Doing self guided Chinatown walk, I ended up here to get some goodies.  It was crowded inside, with lots of people ordering pastries. They have all different types from sweet to savory. I ended up sticking with the sweet pastries, ordering the durian bun, green tea and red tea bun, and egg tart.  I also ordered the taro bun, but the server seemed to have missed that one, as I think she only spoke Chinese. 

The durian bun was sweet and buttery.  Really good as I was expecting something different. I still have to eat the remaining two, so I am a happy camper!
author: Marck N.

description:
I love their Ma Tsai! 

My favorite bakery in Chinatown: AA Bakery (for egg tart), Napoleon (for ma tsai), Eastern Bakery (for dan san and ma tsai) and Wa Li (for buns).
author: Ashley C.

description:
I've been here so many times and I've always had a great experience. They churn out egg tarts so often and have relatively short lines, which means that you will have access to warm and fresh egg tarts during much of the day.

$0.70 per egg tart!!
author: Jason T.

description: My fave bakery in Chinatown. The bbq buns are zee best(eating one right now ;)! We usually pick up a dozen or more whenever we're here. Their plain cupcakes are pretty good, too(I usually pick up 3 or 4). The prices are reasonable and you usually get your orders right away. They're always busy whenever I come (on the weekends).  Just make your way to the counter, get one of the employees attention and tell them what you want. It's not first come, first service here. lol
author: Vicky L.

description: I love, love, love their buns.  Whenever I'm in that neighborhood, I buy a boxful.  Our family favs are taro, pork floss, durian, and custard.  All very reasonably priced too. The customer service is non-existent, but that's ok with me.
author: S L.

description:
Awful service, they flat out ignored me when I stood in front of the glass for 12 MINUTES (eye contact, smiling) . Everyone else shoving and shouting got their food (apparently there is no civility with ghetto Chinese people). Very rude people and even for C-town it was gross and disgusting interior wise and I'm questioning their cleanliness. It's very embarrassing for Chinese people to be so impolite!

1 star for the price and food (since the last time my friend brought me some it was decent and I didn't get sick).
author: Nina B.

description:
One of many small mom and pop hole in the wall hong kong style bakery in Chinatown. 

It was crowded and it was loud.  Don't expect polite and courteous service.  It's all business here. Get to the front, know what you want, make eye contact, and yell or point what you want. Pay and get out. There really is no line... Just shuffle through other patrons, cut through and order before anyone else can butt in, it's the Chinese way.

The most popular item is of course the egg custard tart.  It comes out fresh because it sells out before it can come out of its metal molding.  So good and cheap. 70cents a tart, beats the going rate in San Jose.

The egg tarts here are big with plenty of custard filling.  The crust is flaky , buttery, and warm.  The custard is delicious. The tarts themselves were worth the hour drive to SF.
author: Ronnie N.

description: Get in there early on a Saturday, make your way to the front of the line (at the back of the shop), past all the local grannies picking up treats for their grandchildren and get your hands on some piping hot egg tarts fresh out of the oven...
author: Isabelle G.

description: Get their hot pastries, they are very good. Especially their durian bun, I just ate 3 this morning...
author: Jessica C.

description:
Crazy how fast paced everything was moving around me. If you don't step up quick to make your order, you may have to wait quite a long time to put in a request for buns.

Glad I came with my buddy who was able to help me with some language barriers, but any person can come through and buy great cheap food. Highly recommend grabbing some quick eats while out on the town here.
author: Michael M.

description:
A question that I've pondered from time to time but am now only putting down into words:  Why do Chinese bakeries make lopsided cakes?  Lopsided meaning the bottom or top layer of the cake is uneven therefore the baker will pipe in more cream on one side of the cake so the finished product won't look like a crooked mess.

Super Napolean and a lot of the SF bakeries are guilty of making crooked cakes.  So is it crooked because they sliced the tops off wrong?  Maybe someone should go back to cooking 101 to relearn the basics?

Anyway, we got a mixed fruit cake from SN.  Yup, the cake was crooked.  Yup one side had more frosting than the other.  The cake was pretty firm and the cream wasn't that sugary.  Fruit includes, strawberry, peaches, pineapple, lichee, honeydew and cantelope.  From the first bite, I could taste a whiff of canned fruit syrup (I am hoping they didn't dump that into the cake when they made it) but that taste was fleeting and I didn't taste it in the subsequent bites.

Cake was put in this fancy round box that you see in the Victorian ages.  It's really nice but I'm sure they built that into the price of the cake as well.

It's OK.
author: Wendy H.

description:
food: pineapple bun and egg tart. classic breakfast/brunch food. the crust on the bun is crunchy and just sweet enough on every bite of the bun. the egg tart is a good alternative to the other popular bakery. still flaky on the crust and the custard is gooey and soft especially when its still warm from the oven. ***5/5

service: it can get hectic whens there a lot of people. theres no line system really. you just have to be in there face and know what you want. you have you squeeze your way in sometimes. but once you get someones attention, youre good to go. they have signs in front of the pastries with the name and price on it. ***3/5

atmosphere: its a decent size place for a bakery. a few spots for people to sit when needed. but when its crowded, you might as well just leave and try to come back later. ***3/5

value: a bit more than a dollar for 2 items. try that at any other bakery. ***5/5
author: Andy Z.

description: Got here just as they were pulling out a fresh tray of egg tarts - what luck! There is really no line or system in place to order - so just push your way to the counter and  hope you can flag on of the ladies down. Eventually I was able to order 6 egg tarts all for $4.20. What a steal. My gal threw my tarts in a small pink box that had little vents cut out and tied it with plastic string. Terrific. The hardest part was wading through the tourists and the Chinese ladies doing their daily grocery shopping. I wouldn't even consider parking anywhere close. Taste wise - I prefer Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts because they are sweeter - that said, I would never pass on an egg tart from Napoleon!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Thanks Napoleon SUPER Bakery for saving me from the utter disappointment that Golden Gate Bakery was on vacation AGAIN!  We must have gone to over 5 bakeries in Chinatown and passed on them before walking past Napoleon and saw the huge Cantonese speaking crowd inside - this told us we have hit the jackpot.

We ordered egg tarts fresh out of the oven (even a really picky friend of mine tried it and wouldn't stop eating), Durian buns and Custard buns.  My Cantonese speaking friend somehow managed to get me a deal on the buns which ended up getting me 7 Durian/Custard buns for the price of 6.

Definitely a very close substitute to GGB for egg tarts, and I loved the Durian buns (Custard buns were so-so).

Tips: Manners don't matter in here, shove your way to the counter to order as others do (if not, you snooze you lose); people who work here barely speak English so just point to the display case and say how many you want; there are only two small tables with two chairs each so don't expect to dine in; cash only.
author: Annabelle C.

description:
My God! I wish I hadn't already fill myself up so quickly with egg custards and grilled meat here in Chinatown, because Napoleon Bakery has some really good stuffs! Po Lou Bao (similar to Japanese Melon Bun or Mexican Conchas) is small and round with the layer of crispy sweet buttery crust baked right on top. They also have fresh baked bread loaf, rolled cakes, hot dog buns, shredded pork buns, and buns with red bean paste! Oh wow! the red bean was not too sweet, and they didn't skim on it. It was near perfection.

One of Napoleon's famous selling is the Duran bun. If you are not familiar with duran, it is a fruit indigenous to Southeast Asia; hard, prickly shell on the outside, hiding a soft and smooth and sweet fruit center. However, all those features are overshadowed by the pungent smell as you break the shell open. There aren't many that can stand the smell. Like another very localized Chinese dish, yes I'm talking about the stinky tofus, if you can stand the smell, it is really the best thing you could have tasted.

Another one of their selling point might be their cakes, which are freshly made with whipped cream and not those sugary one from the super market, which makes it easy (and less guilt) to take in and actually enjoy the occasion celebrated.
author: Kuanyu C.

description: They have Durian Bao, I didn't know they existed until a couple months ago. Smelly? Yes. Real? Yes, it has the whole stringy texture and all. I like the stuff on top of the bao, it has like a pineapple bun or Mexican bun type topping but rolled into pine nut shaped topping.
author: Kylie L.

description: The mini-pineapple buns with custard filling is pretty delicious here.  They are like 5 for $1.30 which is a great deal.  And, egg tarts for 0.70 cents!  Just like everyone says, you need to push and be aggressive since no one understands the concept of taking turns or forming a line.  If you are passive, make sure you bring someone who is aggressive!
author: Jenn W.

description:
Came here with my brother and fiance after I saw the sign on Golden Gate Bakery's front door that said on vacation. 
I first have to tell you that Ronnie N's review of this place is dead on about the type of business/ service you get. You really have to be aggressive to get the baked goodies that you came in here for, if you don't muscle your way in, you won't ever get served because there is always some other customer in here trying to jump in line ahead of you (like this one guy who tried to get helped before me... I can be aggressive too, especially if there are egg tarts involved). 
Anyways, I only came in here for egg tarts and lucky for me, I was able to get the last 6 fresh out of the oven egg tarts (which are 0.70 each by the way). Since I asked for 7, the lady helping me behind the display case gave me this egg tart with a hole in it. I ate that egg tart with the hole in it and it still tasted good.
But anyways, the egg tart here has a nice eggy taste. It was deliciously devoured by my family. But my brother, fiance and I wanted to do an egg tart face off between these egg tarts and the ones from AA Bakery (which is right across the street from this bakery). My brother and I felt that the egg tart from AA Bakery were sweeter and didn't have that strong egg like taste like Napolean's. My fiance said he couldn't tell, lol but he wasn't really trying both of the egg tarts for comparison. He just wolfed them down because that's kind of how he usually eats his food (yea he needs to take some time to maybe chew and breath in between bites).
