But even though my brother and I like AA Bakery's egg tarts a little bit better, the egg tarts here are still very good and at the right price (at AA Bakery, they are a whopping $1.00! each). 
Would come back here again and be ready to push my way to the front to get my egg tarts. (Oh and by the way, cash only here and you can order here in English if you don't speak Chinese).
author: Vic C.

description:
I've not tried their cakes here.  My mom use to buy her pastries here.  I will buy their egg tarts, but really prefer AA Bakeries egg custards.  

The disorganized method that they use to serve customers is enough to make you walk out of this establishment.  No lines, just massive people jumping in front of others who've been waiting to get served too.  It's nuts.  I can't deal so I often don't go in.  There are too many other bakeries in Chinatown to try.   

Like most places in Chinatown, they don't speak English here & you better know what you want & point to it!  It's Chinatown.
author: Marie E.

description:
Cha-sui bao (baked) = nice size.  And delicious. The large ones are 80 cents each!  Trust me...it's good.  (Personally, they don't get the four stars from me because they have too much of what I call 'marshmallow bread')  

Custard bun = okay.  I'm not a fan of the baked ones.  I prefer them steamed. :P 

Service = friendly, efficient, and some English-speaking.

Per usual, Chinese bakeries, bring cold hard cash.
author: Fannie S.

description:
They have DURIAN CAKE!!  I called in the morning to inquire and they do indeed make it.  I searched "durian" and this bakery came up.. i'm so so happy to have found them.  I ordered an 8" cake for $20.  I believe it was made with fresh durian - didn't taste frozen.  It's one layer of yellow sponge cake (moist enough, spongey) with a middle layer of durian, and then another layer of sponge cake and topped with a light frosting and fruit (melons and strawberries for mine).  I would highly recommend careful carrying of this cake as durian is slippery and the two cake layers shifted like two plates under the earth.  The shifting eventually smashed up the cake but no matter - it tasted great!  I believe the shifting was my fault anyways.  I should've been more careful swinging that bag around while walking... 

This is next door to a dim sum bakery that had a short line coming out of it.  The shu mai is great at this bakery and according to Yelpers the shrimp dumpling is good too.  So get your meaty dim sum at that bakery on your way to picking up a durian cake from Napoleon :)

Oh and Napoleon also makes Sachima (google it) - it's not very crispy but it has coconut on it if you like.

Cash only but there's a Wells Fargo ATM on the same block.
author: Alias A.

description:
On the quest to find the best soft pineapple bun, Napoleon Dynamite Super Bakery sure does make a mean one. 

Not too sweet, nice flakey crunchy crust on the outside, and moist and soft on the inside. 

Like Napoleon Dynamite talking about the Liger, "It's pretty much my favorite bun, it's like a pineapple and dinner roll mixed...bred for it's tastes in deliciousness."
author: Earl G.

description:
BOR LOR BAO!! 

For those of you don't understand Cantonese, Bor Lor Bao pretty much means "pineapple bun".  And if you have ever try pineapple bun before, this place really has ones with quality.  

Located in Chinatown...I absolutely hate walking around the wet, dirty, loud streets of the area.  But I must say, Chinatown really has its own good and unique self.  I come here probably 2-3 times a month.  The reason why i would come out here is to visit my grandparents.  But at the same time, stock up for food at home.  Things really are cheaper out here.  

Napoleon bakery is always packed! There is usually a line...a LONGER line if they just bring out the fresh, steamy, soft pineapple buns from the oven! OHH SOOO GOOD!  If you come here late evening, around 5 - 6pm, you're less likely to have options, because most of their buns will be sold out.  

I also love their egg tarts, the buns with corn, mayonnaise, and ham on it.  The prices are absolutely reasonable.  Sometimes I bring home a box of 12, mixed with a variety of different buns.  Hey! It is pretty good for breakfast! Heat it up in the oven and you're good to go!

p.s. make sure you bring cash!
author: Stephy L.

description:
GG Bakery was closed! It seems as if they're always closed for vacation, which is a big disappointment because you just never know when they're open! 

Anyways, Napoleon you did a SUPER job on being the next best egg tart substitute! Who doesn't like a good don tot?!
author: Jeanette Y.

description: The nai wong baus are very tasty here, containing a custard filling that is light and having just the right amount of sweet without giving you cavities. When I bought them there were a lot (and I mean a whole lotta) cash-waving "paw paws" all saying that they were next in line. I survived.
author: Derek N.

description: I go there to get my cake roll.  It's soooo good and fresh.  I like the container too as it protects the cake roll from getting crushed while transporting it.  I won't say what flavor, otherwise it will sell out too fast, LOL  =)  I've also come here for my Dad's 70th and 75th birthday cake to serve about 30 people.  I grew up with this kind of fluffy cake with fruit.  My favorite.  American desserts are usually way too sweet.  Their cakes are just light, fluffy and light on the sugar.
author: Deborah C.

description:
The crowds parted on Stockton.. and alas a bakery stood still.. bustling and fully stocked so I could buy all sorts of lovely concoctions.

SD is fabulous. But I have yet to come across the Classic Chinese Bakery, and this place is finally on my list.  In the midst of Stockton, this bakery has it. Most items are $.80! Crazy!

- Hot Dog Bao: Yummyness and delish! 
- Ham/Corn: Hello love! This is just an uberness of mayo.
- Custard Roll thing: Hi :) I'll be on the treadmill an extra hr.. but its worth it.
- Scallion/Pork: What the hell was this? All I know is.. um! can I get another?

It's a good thing this place is not accessible to me, because I would be a big ole tubo of Chinese Baked Goodness all the time.  But for now, it's simply perfection.
author: Natalie G.

description:
I have a long story about this busy bakery in the heart of Chinatown. 
It is the busiest bakery in chinatown. They have two bakeries, one in SF Chinatown and Oakland Chinatown. Both bakeries rocks.
Oakland bakery is the biggest in square feet of the two. People who shops in chinatown, have a foul sweatty workout, in fighting the crowd in neighborring produce market. I have a wide body and i cover up the pastry counter. AS I wait, little ladies, who wants service, wave their large dollar bills at the ladies behind the counter to serve them. I've waited ten minute just to order an inexpensive pastry. This little lady just came in to the door,who demands immediate service in a rude way, complained to ladies behind the counter, that she waited an eternity to be waited on. I hate to wait in line for anything as I mentioned in the Chinatown Walgreens and Pancho Villa taqueria. But for cheap pastries is worth the wait, eventhough coming here and to be served is a nightmare.
Whenever I get what I want, there pastries is out of this world. They have sweet and savory pastries. I also mentioned coffee in Chinatown is not worth getting sick over, the decanter filled with coffee has in the heater for 2-3 hours. When purchasing your pastry @ this location you must leave, they have 4 tables in that crampped bakery. You can't enjoy food in this small bakery. Most of the pastries are under $.70. If you are under budget, buying two savory pastries can fill you up.
My favorite sweet pastries are:
1.Custard tart & Custard roll (Bau)
2. Raisin Roll
3. Napoleon cake
my favorite savory pastry are:
1.Chicken and tomato 
2. breaded fish covered parmesan coatted bread
3. Old-fashion Ham & egg
*With the tough Chinatown crowd, i had all the pastry there. They are good and inexpensive
author: Matt G.

description: Love their Egg tarts and Durian buns. Their Egg tarts are the best when it comes right our of the oven, freshly baked. The crust is nice and crunchy. The size of their Egg tarts are more towards the larger end, which makes it worth it for its price.
author: Victor Z.

description:
Ordered to take out...a cake & egg tarts.

The egg tarts...they make the shell in a buttery flaky French Croissant pastry style.  The filling has a strong egg yolk taste.  While I like this way of making the tarts, I also like the tarts from bakeries which make a crumbly crust with a milder tasting filling.

The cake...9 inch round fruit cake.  The cake layers are light, perfectly sweetened, with a melt in your mouth texture.   They put too much canned fruit filling in the middle.  So when you cut the slices they do not hold their shape.  The slice becomes an unrecognizable pile of canned fruit, cake, & frosting.  My recommendation...use thicker pieces of cake(it is delicious)...and use less canned fruit in the middle(or use only fresh fruit for filling).  There is nothing special about using extra canned fruit for a filling.
author: Saul M.

description:
I used to be a fan of Napolean, but I recently returned and found that the service was not only awful, but the bread was not that fresh. The crusts of the pineapple breads are very crumbly and rather dry, and the fillings were okay. I wasn't inclined to finish my pastries...which was unusual. (I got a Pineapple Taro Bun, Pineapple Egg Custard Bun, and a Fish and Cheese Bun.)

Also, the lady at the counter served the woman who came in after me before attending to me. She was extremely sullen.
author: K W.

description: I agree, they do have the BEST egg tarts in town!! I'm not from San Francisco so I relied on my Chinese foodies there.   My cousin who frequents Chinatown highly recommended Napoleon Super Bakery over the all touristy Golden Gate Bakery.  She said Napolean's is cheaper and fresher.  As soon as I walked into the store, there was a line forming to the back of the store where the egg tarts just came out of the oven.  People were purchasing them by the boxes. When there is a line, I MUST follow.... they were super tasty, pastry shell had the perfect fluffyness, fresh hot and I think they were like $0.80 a piece. Always listen to the locals, they know what they are talking about. Yummilicious!!
author: M O.

description:
I used to go to the one in oakland chinatown before I discovered that one in SF chinatown. The place looks like a dingy hole in the wall, its not very well lit and its been around for such a long time that I think the grime has built up. But I grew up in the city and have learned appearances are deceiving. 
The prices are still pretty decent (they used to be much cheaper, but alas inflation). 
I get the pineapple buns, wifecakes, and egg tarts here. Everything is very fresh. You need to compete with all the Chinatown folks to get the attention of the servers behind the counter, but its well worth it.
author: Caroline C.

description:
The trick is to wiggle your way in the line in order to grab the a clerk's attention. Whenever you see an opening, take charge! That is what I learned since the bakery is crowded!

My sister and I love the pineapple bread and bbq pork buns. the buns are so delicious when it's fresh! I'm craving for some now...
author: Jackie S.

description:
I only go here for one thing after I visit New Asia for dim sum... FRESH BAKED RED BEAN BUNS FOR 50 CENTS. They're huge, cheap, warm, and tasty. I love the yellow crumbly sweet stuff on top of the soft, tasty, bun that falls everywhere with each bite and the sweet red bean on the inside counters this crispiness. Be sure to ask them for the freshly baked buns, not the ones in the display case, everytime I go it seems there's a fresh batch in the back. 4 stars because this is all I like there, but it makes for a perfect dessert after a short walk from any of the dim sum spots in the area.

UPDATE: I just came from here today and the buns are now 60 cents... but still damn good!!! I also uploaded photos of the buns along with the store itself up there in that photo thing. Check 'em out!
author: Albert B.

description: They have lemon rolls!!!! I went here for the bbq pork buns and they are good, but I've had better. But the lemon roll is what you want! A light fluffy vanilla cake rolled in lemon curd. YUM!!
author: Jaime K.

description:
I went here today, Weds 9/14, and the place was closed. It was boarded up and had some kind of official sign on the front (perhaps an eviction sign). From the date listed on the sign, it had been there for weeks. 

There was also a hand written unofficial sign on the door that said "Open 9/15". I assumed that meant they are reopening on 9/15? Not sure but I'm glad AA was across the street selling discounted bread so I could pick up my buns!
author: Leslie W.

description:
Located between two barbecue joints on Stockton street, Napoleon Super Bakery is an uncut gem hidden in the Chinatown jungle. Their glass storefront and orange awning blend into the background; however, to the trained eye, the dull, metallic racks holding fresh pastries and the crowds of loyal patrons are telltale signs of brilliance.

Entering the fray, customers half your size will challenge you at the counter. Leave your fear at the door. Step up, make eye contact, and shout out your order with confidence. If they are about to place second-rate goods in your rose-colored box, be sure to voice your concern. You will be rewarded.

On Saturday and Sunday afternoons, there frequently are fresh, piping hot egg tarts -- delicate, light egg custard in a flaky pie crust. For those looking for something sweet, the "cocktail" bun (gai mei bao) and the fresh cream pastry (lai you bao) are enjoyable pastries; yet they may not completely satisfy the sugar craving as Chinese pastries are less saccharine than their Western counterparts. This explains the frequent substitution of mango for chocolate. For savory pastries, the flaky, curry turnover (ga lei gok) and the barbecue pork bun (char siu bao) are excellent options. The savory pastries balance the saltiness of the fillings with the slight sweetness of the soft pastry, similar to a Russian piroshki.

In the case of a birthday party or other gathering, the chestnut cake is a good choice. The sweet, nutty flavor combines nicely with the light, airy cake, light cream frosting, and fresh fruit. Ordering ahead is advised.
author: Alex C.

description:
=Super Napolean Bakery=

Lots of yummy breads here. If you want some good chinese bakery, you will come here! Cheap and tasty. 

I love their custard bun. The pork bun is a little too dry for me.
author: Christopher J.

description: Ordered another chestnut BDay cake from Napoleon.  Quick, cheap & good and ready in a hour.  Not as good as my childhood favorite chestnut cake from HK, but close enough.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This bakery is superb, which is right across the street from The AA Bakery - another of my favorites in town.

I love egg and ham buns, and strangely - The AA Bakery's just doesn't match those from Napoleon.  Napoleon's egg is a layered spongy egg (somewhat like what the Japanese would put on top of sushi) where as The AA just pan frys their egg, and that's why I'd come here for lunch or a quick snack when I can.

Oh, FYI, their baked chicken bun is a must try, it's topped with shredded seaweed & their egg tarts are just as good as those from Golden Gate Bakery, MMMMM.

Plus a bottle of Wong Lo Kat drink, yum!
author: Alex C.

description: The egg custard is ok but I like the flakey crust more so I typically don't get the egg custard here.  I really like the sponge cake (they call it cupcake) and durian buns. The sponge cake is fluffy and not very sweet just the way I like it.  I would prefer the durian filling to be a little less sweet but I still enjoy it.  There's usually a line in the bakery when I go but not a bad wait and the line is never out the door.  Price is very reasonable.  I definitely always make a stop for the sponge cake and durian buns when I go to Chinatown.
author: San H.

description:
I was absolutely amazed at how the egg tarts were sold at all the dim sum places that I went to in SF today...however maybe it was a good thing that happend because it eventually led me to Napoleon!

OMG, the egg tarts here are DELICIOUS.  I bought 2 egg tarts for $1.40 = super cheap!  It was still warm when I bought it, and the crust was very flaky and the egg tart totally delectable! Yumm!
author: Patty O.

description:
sooooooooooooooooooo
gooooooooooooooooood

They've never failed me.

SPONGE CAKES
PINEAPPLE BUNS
EGG TARTS

cash only!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
IMO, this place has the best egg tarts in Chinatown.  It's certainly the best value at 50 cents each (compared to Golden Gate Bakery nearby with their gimmicky warm egg tarts at a whopping $1.15 each!)

I come here often to order their strawberry whip cream sponge cake for occasions as well.  I think the cakes are so moist and fluffy here!  They're pretty generous with the fresh fruit filling as well.

As others have mentioned, service is pretty bad here but I'm totally accustomed to it so it doesn't bother me at all.
author: Jennifer I.

description:
I have only tried two items here:

1. Sweet bun with mayo and shredded pork

2. Pineapple bun

This two items make me want to sing "Baby you da best, the best I ever had, best I ever had."

Minus one star for lack of parking, sign for the store isn't really visible, and they don't speak english so it's hard for non Chinese speakers to communicate what they want, it doesn't help that they don't have many items on display to simply point to either.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Been going here for years! I remember when the raisin bun was 50c instead of 80. When dinner rolls were 35 instead of 50 etc etc. Ok prices go up and inflation blows. That being said, you can still get a good snack / light meal for only a dollar or two, and really, how can you beat that?

I say light meal, because ... it's probably not very good for you to have your whole meal consisting of carbs, dried fruit, meats, cheese, and umm... mayo.

So, how's this all work? You elbow your way in (shove the old ladies if needed, trust me... they're RUTHLESS) and get the attention of one of the staff ladies. Ok .. back up. Figure out what you're going to get, and then catch the attention of the staff.

I SWEAR this is just like friday night / saturday night at the bar. You got a whole crush of people mobbing the counter, and everyone's itching for their fix. So. Bar rules apply. Have your money out, and be clear and concise about what you want to order. Count it out as your drink is being made ... err ... buns are being bagged... and present cash when they come back with your order. 

Dont stand there and gawk, dont ask a million questions, and dont get in the way. There are tons of people and they're all going to glare at the back of your head when you start asking questions or fumble for cash at the last second. Since old ladies are passive aggressive, they'll probably just step on your shoe accidentally-on purpose as you step out of the establishment.

Let's recap
1) Recon - figure out what you want
2) Bait - draw their attention
3) Order - issue commands to the staff
4) Funds - cash. get it out. count it bucko.
5) Secure provisions, Funds transfer - Grab bag, handover cash (and cash only)
6) Escape the awaiting stomps of the restless natives.
7) Enjoy and Yelp!
author: Tyrone B.

description: FANTASTIC fruit cakes and egg tarts.  Simply the BEST in the city.  Eat your heart out
author: Virginia C.

description: My aunt picked up a cake on thanksgiving day for our family dinner and the cardboard tray and bottom of the cake WAS COVERED IN MOLD!!! IT WAS SO DISGUSTING. We threw out the whole thing. Luckily it was at the end of the meal and we had other desserts so the night was entirely ruined.  Afterwards, my sister told me that while she was cutting the cake, the cream on the sides was thick and hard to cut through, not soft and creamy like it should have been if it had been fresh.  I am never ever coming back and would WARN ANYONE THINKING ABOUT COMING HERE.  my aunt and grandparents said that the stuff from here is usually fine, but even if this is a one time occurrence, it's a really disappointing and unforgivable one.
author: Denise C.

description:
I grew up with this bakery, so its hard to give this spot a bad review. each bread, bun that they have is made so fresh that I can not stop myself from drooling on the keyboard. they say that NY and SF bread taste different because air of the environment affects the  yeast, which is very true. San Francisco bread, bun tends to be more moist. although it maybe intimidating to go in there not know English or Cantonese/Tai Shanese, there are signs translated for each bread/bun and they dont mind if you point.  

but when they do pricing don't be confused if you see then don't use the register they all worked there for more thee 10 years
author: Peter Y.

description:
Let me teach you how to buy things in Chinatown.  You have to be pushy.  Yes, PUSHY.  You think those little Asian women are going to be small and unassuming and stand quietly in a queue?  HA.  You are horrendously wrong.  One of those little Chinese grandmas can probably whup your butt without batting an eye, step over your prostrate body, and wave a wad of cash at the bakery servers.  All while scolding you in a fluid string of Cantonese.

So I've learned.  The hard way.  

The first time I went into this bakery, I waited like any other "normal" American.  But I rapidly realized that it was an eat or be eaten world.  If I didn't act proactively, I would be waiting forever and a day.  I soon pushed (or was pushed?  I'm not sure anymore) to the counter, and, luckily, with my height and inner pushy, Asian grandma (never knew I had it in me, but I guess I know what I'll be like when I'm old and decrepit . . . ), managed to secure several cha siu baos and pineapple breads for myself.  

Since then, I've gone back various times.  The cha siu baos and the plain, pullman loafs and pork sung breads are good.  So are the egg tarts and fa gao.  I stopped by today during my early morning run to pick up some bao for breakfast.  Yum.  And there aren't nearly as many people being pushy in the morning.
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
This review is for all you durian lovers. This place gets 5 stars for having a yummy durian bun...a tad expensive, but hey, where else outside of Vancouver can you get anything durian? Not too sweet, texture of bun is perfect with a nice crunchy topping to add interest and flavor. Wished they put more filling though (that's just my taste) since it's not too sweet so that I'd get more durian goodness in every bite. Not available till 11am on the day I went. My mother will be coming here everyday if she could. 

Other treats are good as well. You just have to put up with the "service" prevalent in CT establishments. The ladies have to deal with an ornery crowd thus their attitude also reflect this...just chalk it up to the frenzy buying culture, experience a more direct no non-sense style of customer service, get your goods and go enjoy the yummy goodies!
author: Lil D.

description: This is hands down the freshest bakery in Chinatown. They sell so many buns and pastries that items are always warm and hot. They are fast and efficient and without the line out the door or the attitude of Golden Gate Bakery. I am sitting here thinking about their soft sponge roll cakes.
author: Tina C.

description: The little 4 for $1 sponge cakes are not the best but they sure are cheap!!!  I bought 16 for only $4
author: B L.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. It's not because it's on the same block that my mom gave birth to me (the hospital is around the corner), but it has all my favorite buns.  From egg tarts to sliced custard bread...you can have it all.  This place can get pretty busy. Here's some tips so you can get outta there quickly:

-know what you want.  No hmming and hawwing when there are tons of other people who will be helped before you since there's no real line system
-have your money ready
-make sure you get noticed

Their BBQ pork buns (which are baked, not steamed) are to die for and their egg tarts are off the hook.  You'll probably want to buy egg tarts around 1 or 2PM because that's when they have fresh ones.  The ones in the morning may be from the day before. The prices are so amazing that you'll leave with a box full of buns!
author: Lisa X.

description: Bleh....supposively this is runner up when golden gate bakery is close. I don't think so! We thought we would bring back a few dozens of baked goods for the family (as we were planning to do so from the other bakery. The quality was subpar, yet it was crowded. I don't understand. Anyhow, they didn't charge us the full amount for the egg tart....she must have miscalculated. Either way, I will NOT go back..
author: Susan L.

description:
3.5 stars

We got a pineapple bun w/ custard filling - $0.70?  The lady pulled it out from the glass case so it wasn't fresh from the oven.  The bottom has a piece of paper, which I promptly pulled off.  

I was disappointed that the pineapple crust on top was very small - the right one should cover the entire surface of the bun.  It took us a few bites before getting the custard filling but it was good when we finally tasted it.  The bun was reasonably soft. 

I will give them another try, hopefully with something fresh from the oven and I shall try their cocktail bun.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Yes, the buns are a steal here compared to other bakeries. Yes, I found out the true meaning of you get what you pay for. Meaning quality is not up to par  when prices are so cheap and saying the buns are decent here is an overstatement. 

- Mini sponge cakes wrapped in wax paper: Very bland. I only tasted a hint of sugar like they had to ration it due to our harsh economic times? I don't know.  I got a whiff of the delicious egg scent that is associated with sponge cake, but sadly did not taste it at all.

- Plain pineapple bun: soft inside, crispy yellow topping on the outside. It was good, but again I tasted the lack of sweetness. I liked the fluffy insides, but this one just didn't do it for me.

 I love pineapple buns, but why does the crust always have to fall all over the place into a mess (this goes for all the pineapple buns that I've tried at various places), WHY? Definitely not a good on the go item to eat.
author: Tracy T.

description: As another yelper mentioned, Golden Gate Bakery was closed...again.  And by that time, I had a crazy craving for some egg tarts, so I did a quick yelp search + ended up here.  Typical Chinese bakery...no lines, so be prepared to squeeze your way to the front + just scream your order out.  (I hate places like this + probably a good 3 or 4 Chinese women that showed up after me got their orders first.)  Egg tarts were 70 cents each.  I know GG egg tarts are $1.25...so +++ for Napoleon.  I can't compare to GG since I never had them there, but the Napoleon ones were excellent.  Super deep + flaky crust, with LOTS of yummy custard.  When I was ordering, I kept asking the bf if he was sure he only wanted one.  The of course when he finished it, he was like...that's it???  Be smart and buy more :)
author: Jennifer C.

description: Alway good. Especially the baked Char Siu Bao, but also try the sponge cake, cakes, pineapple buns and cocktail buns. Authentic Hong Kong Style bakery. Lines? What Line? Must be aggressive or customers will cut in front of you. But don't take it personally cuz thats how it works in Chinatown.
author: Les W.

description:
Have waited out here seemingly millions of times while sis is inside picking up her order. She's finally gotten smart and calls in her order and all she has to do is show up later and pick that order up. 

This place is always jammed full except at 7am!! I have seen a few non-asians within (trying to) and they are always there for the longest time. hahahahaaa  I get to taste everything she buys here and all good, tasty and fresh!! I especially love the lemon rolls that I buy and take to Eugene (like tomorrow when I drive up again). Very delicious with a strong lemon taste so if you like lemons, this is your dessert!! Too many things that's good so just go and try for yourself.

In reference to people cutting in front of you: that also happens in Europe/Spain too; natives get impatient with "tourists" who take (much) longer so they cut in front. Keep track of your position in the crowd/line and maintain your position!!!! With repeat trips here and practice, soon you'll be cutting in front of "them"!!! hahahahaa
author: Tony L.

description:
This place was not bad back with baos were 60 cents each.... its still alright but i would say it's not as good.... and for another thing.. their cakes!.... hmmm first time we had the mango mousse cake it was delicious and yummalicious!.... but then everytime i get it for my birthday.. i ended up getting a salty spongecake for the spongecake part... correct me if im wrong, but isnt cake supposed to be sweet? O-o i mean on other occasions, the spongecake part is fine... its just for my birthday when they taste salty! :[

-x3 shells
author: Lily X.

description: This bakery has the best deals and a huge variety of Chinese pastries.  Their egg custards are so big, they look like cakes, and if you get them early around 9am, they're hot & fresh.  I drive to this side of town to stock up for the week, whereas I usually stop in Clement...parking is easier.  Their prices are unbeatable, and everything is enormous!  My son loves their raisin bread, and he eats one loaf in a serving.  It's cheaper to clothe him than to feed him LOL:=)
author: Christine R.

description:
I've been coming here for a while now, every time I get the chance go to SF. I have to say, they're definitely runner-up to the Golden Gate Bakery egg tarts. It's cheaper and you definitely can avoid the long line. They also have other goodies such as Taro buns, Green bean buns, Red bean buns, very very yummy!

A must when I go to SF!
author: Joyce B.

description:
I go here for one thing: the pork sung/rousong buns.  For those of you who do not know, a pork sung bun is essentially a baked roll with pork sung adhered to it with mayo.  I know it sounds questionable, but it is so, SO good.

Word to the wise: like most authentic Chinese establishments, you need to aggressively assert yourself, because despite the appearance of a line, there is no order, and you'll never be assisted if you quietly wait your turn.
author: Jenn C.

description:
This' a must visit bakery for Pineapple Buns whenever I come to San Francisco, and I've had many good pineapple buns in my life. 

Love their freshly made Pineapple Bun with red bean or taro fillings. Sweet crunchy buttery crust with warm chewy dough, it's happiness in every bite!
author: Catherine W.

description:
As Monica N. mentioned, the service is a bit lacking.  

This was my third stop out of five bakeries in Chinatown, and I have to say this one left me a bit bitter.  I was relieved that they had the plain bao that only seemed to be in dim sum restaurant windows, so immediately ordered that.  The lady kept asking if I wanted it, because it was "cold!"  I just nodded my head, "yeah."  She kept on her "are you sure, it's cold" questioning.  The customer is always right, so why couldn't she accept my nodding!?  She even placed in on the counter for me to touch and see for myself how cold it was.  When I still said "yeah," she finally accepted that, but she had to turn to her friend, say something in Chinese, and they both laughed.  So I left feeling like a foolish foreigner in my own country.  Nice.

Paper was stuck to the bun's bottom.
author: Missa P.

description:
Pretty good baked items here. I usually get the cocktail buns (so good when warm), the red bean filled pineapple buns or raisin bread. Their pricing is decent and quality is good.

Service wise, you must be agressive! Make eye contact and yell out what you want as soon as they look at you, or else be prepared to wait and wait even though you were already waiting for a long time. Cash only!
author: Linda C.

description: My family's favorite bakery to hit up while we are in San Francisco China Town. This place is generally packed and if your arrive late on a busy day they're practically sold out. My favorite pastries includes durian custard buns (especially delicious when they're fresh) and their huge egg tarts. I've also tried their napoleon pastry, which was supposedly the store's special considering their store is named after it and it wasn't too impressive. Check out napoleon bakery if you're in the area. I always grab a box or two to go, but would be lucky to still have a box left by the time I arrive home.
author: Cat T.

description:
I was reading SFist, and they posted a link to Cleanscores. 

When I used to work in restaurants, I remember when the health dept folks would show up. We'd quickly scurry to remove evidence of all the things we hadn't been doing.. like using ice scoops, or clean rags to wipe down tables. 

We'd hide the ashtrays, wash our hands, try to refrain from coughing or sneezing,  and put on a good show for the inspectors. 

Somehow they would miss the  teeming cockroach population, the grease buildup, and general filthiness of the place, and just site us for a couple of minor things. 

We'd still clear with a good score (high 80s/low 90s), and promise to fix the bad. 

Anyway, I was browsing the website, and checking out the scores of a few places that I like.. they didn't rate so bad. I was saddened by the ones that did. 

Then I found their list of the worst (32 that scored below 80)
www.cleanscores.com/browse/worst

Some score in the 70s.. I mean, hey .. they're trying. You're stuck in older buildings. Some of those rat and cockroaches have ancestors who have been living here for far longer than the rest of us.. how can you really get rid of them? 

But the fun ones.. are the ones that score below 50.
I found a few (and didn't recognize them as places I had eaten.. but who knows. I'll eat just about anywhere. Even those $1.00/item steam tables)

After I read a few I thought, "I wonder how many of these places have awesome reviews in Yelp?"

This one does!

(p.s. - In case you're curious.. they got scored a 42)

http://www.cleanscores.com/1187/Napoleon+Super+Bakery
author: I M.

description:
Napolean was rated the most dirty bakery in SF. If you know anything about Chinatown in SF, you know that when its dirty, its DIRRRRRRTY. Sometimes I'll make the quick trek across the dirty Stockton tunnel on my lunch breaks and head over to Napolean to grab some buns. 
They have these mini pineapple-buns with red bean or custard filling that costs only $1.10/4. Those little suckers are pretty good, so if you think you have the stomache to handle it, go for it. The secret to not getting moldy-cakes and buns are to purchase their popular items, that way you know you're getting the fresh batch because everyone else is buying them. Their popular items are the: mini pineapple buns, sliced bread and cupcakes that are really sponge-cakes in disguise.
author: Nancie T.

description:
This place is known for their egg tarts, but once you have tried Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts, there is no better in S.F.

I even changed my brother's mind about that.  He claimed this place was the best, i proved him wrong, so wrong.

It's alright, theyre pretty big egg tarts.
author: kim w.

description: Fantastic cakes at great prices. I got the white cake with fresh fruit on top and it was delicious. Light and sweetened perfectly. Cream was not overwhelming and in proportion with the cake. They do a great job to personalize names with the icing and service was very quick. Solid bakery.
author: Ed L.

description:
The brazen and chinese speaking are encouraged to go here.  To get your order taken in this overcrowded, tiny bakery, you, like Yan M. said, you have to push and shove your way through to the front to get one of the ladies' attention.  My bf's mom, who speaks Chinese was intimidated to push to the front, so I did the honors and made my way up to get our order taken.  Make sure you ask if there are egg tarts because they are AWESOME when they come out of the oven.  They're normally all snatched up as soon as they come out of the oven.  I haven't tried too many other things, but they have these really soft cupcakes at 4 for $1.00, how can you beat that!?  Also tried their birthday cakes, which were also very good, I love the Chinatown style birthday cakes, with the sponge cake, layed with cream and fruit.  This one had long-an in them. 

But when you get a chance, pop into this small bakery, it's got lots of good eats!
author: Winnie L.

description: Best coconut bun ever, 5 stars. Baked BBQ pork bun was so so, 2.5 stars
author: A A.

description:
Very good egg custard tart, MUCH BETTER than Golden gate bakery. Much cheaper too. I would suggest people go knowing what they want. Otherwise a pretty chaotic place.

Cheap but good bread for sure.
author: Yuchi C.

description: Well towards closing time is a great way to get a real discount. After dinner in North Beach, my pal and I went to Chinatown and got 2 huge cocktail buns and 1 cream filled bun with coconut flakes all for $1.50. We split up everything and it was good.
author: R C.

description:
Stop #2 of the "Chinese Bakery Run"!

My friends liked the piggy on the sign as well so we headed two doors down Stockton from the first place. They immediately got in line and proceeded to buy raisin buns, custard buns and red-bean buns. 

Super cheap and the raisin bun was a hit. I headed over to Stop #3 because they didn't have what I was looking for...
author: Kat H.

description:
WOW AWESOME CHINESE BAKERY! Their Hot Dog bread, cheese with fish fillet bun, corn and ham bun, and custard bolo bao is quite delightful! It's dirt cheap as well... i bought 2 boxes full of buns and it only cost me 16 dollars.. i think there were like 20 something buns.. haha lols! 

Get there early in the morning so everything is fresh, and no long lines compared to the afternoon!
author: Brian P.

description: I love their ham and corn bun!! Their tomato and cheese or ham is pretty good also, only 60cents each! A lot of their buns costs around that much.
author: Janet Z.

description: This is a very busy bakery with moderately priced baked goods.  Everything seemed fresh with high turnover.  Don't expect too much jazzy stuff like bubble tea or other kinds of drinks.
author: ChowNut ..

description:
We had our wedding cake done here. It was fresh and light. The only downside is that when we asked them what kinds of cake they had, they handed us a book. We picked one out and then they said that they didn't have the tools to make it. So we picked another one and they said the same thing. So we asked them which cake they could actually make.

They make good cakes... that old Chinese American style.... light, fluffy, with a lot of cream.... 

My favorite cake is the peanut crumb cake....toasty crumbled peanuts.... sweet cream... light cake... yum. You can't beat that for a birthday cake... unless you're allergic to nuts.

They have a strawberry cake that you can special order. Its much better than their mixed fruit cake.
author: Calvin L.

description: this place can get kinda packed with many moms and grandmas cutting and boxing out for position to purchase decent Chinese pastries at average prices. They have a good selection of the standard and some specials including the natural gas smelling durian bun. But since its chinatown beware of some fishy business practices such as selling old and stale buns from yesterday especially in the early mornings. I recommend the egg tarts though, their flaky crust is one of better ones ive eaten. As with most businesses in chinatown ... cash only. I wouldnt use my credit card in some of the shady chinatown businesses anyways.
author: Robert Y.

description: Good bakery but a little bit dirty
author: Mee G.

description: HEHEHE. I love pineapple buns. They have them here for only 40 cents and it's almost like heaven. But not just pineapple buns, there are also heaps of egg tarts and other delicious Chinese pastries! It's definitely worth your time and money to get a simple snack here.
author: Irene T.

description:
This review is solely for the baked goods so keep that in mind. 

I get excited every time my mom buys a pink boxful of pastries from Napolean! I think my favorites are the raisin buns and the mini pineapple buns with red bean filling. I also enjoy the baked pork buns and the creamed corn/ham buns....mmm! The bread recipe they use for mostly everything is delightfully sweet and fluffy...I love it! It's perfect for just snacking on throughout the day or choose a few different options and there's your meal. I always make a trip here if I'm in the area even if it's just to pick up one raisin bun like I did today. =P Their prices are also ridiculously cheap...most of the buns are 70 or 80 cents...can't beat good quality Chinese pastries for those prices!

Side Note: Yes, the little old Chinese ladies can be rude and cut in line and it's not the cleanest establishment in the world, but it IS Chinatown so what do you expect? Being able to speak Chinese definitely helps too. I still give the food 5 stars!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I come here every time I'm craving Chinese pastries.

They're red bean buns (not sure of the name) are Super!  The best part is, that you can get about a dozen for about $3!  I once ordered only two, and they looked at my like I was crazy.

This is definitely worth trying out if you're in this part of town.  4-stars!

Note to my fellow yelpers: About the line at the counter... there is -no- line.
author: Shea G.

description:
i loveee their buns. they have pineapple regular, pineapple with egg custard *yum* and pineapple with red bean..just for starters. and their cake with the powder sugar on top? drool................

so good i can forgive the wait..the pushy ladies.
author: Whitne Y.

description:
Nice little bakery in the heart of Chinatown--lots of very good, cheap deals for pork buns, egg tarts, bread, etc. Service is crazy inside, mainly because that's how we Chinese roll with things. Just jump right in and call out your order to whoever gives you eye contact first. There's really no formal line in this place.

Today I went in there and I wondered why they even had little tables set up--the environment inside is quite chaotic! I'm surprised anybody would want to sit and 'relax' in there. Oh well; they also have lovely fruit cakes in the front display window, although these are a little pricier than the regular bakery goods to the side.
author: Helene K.

description: I have been eating these pastries since i was a child, growing up on ham & corn, ham & tomato buns, the ham & corn bun is my favorite with corn and ham filling and a mayonnaise sauce right in the middle.  The napoleon is also one of my favorite sweets to eat from here, it is different from the traditional Italian napoleon as it is not made with cream but withsome sort of baked concoction that is sweet and filled with walnuts.  The baked goods here are not that sweet so don't expect a super sweet dessert or bun.  If you are craving a sweet or savory but not too filling sort of bun this place definitely hits the spot, and is so worth it especially at 60 - 80 cents per bun . My favorite part is when you walk in the store and they have a fresh rack of buns pulled straight out of the oven , I will always purchase one of those buns no matter what type it is, because any type of bun tastes delicious when coming out of the oven.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I've only set foot in this fine Chinatown establishment once with my girlfriend.  But my family (my mom in particular) has frequently bought loads of baked goods Napoleon.  I really only like eating the egg custards but I never hear about their other food being bad.

The one time I went there was late in the day right before they were closing.  We found a parking space outside, you know, where it always smells like fish and the streets look like people emptied out the water that the fish were swimming in.  We walked in to buy a cake for er... my mom, I think (gotta love those Chinese cream cakes).  The cake was pretty good but they ran out of egg custards for the day!  I didn't have to deal with the huge crowd since they were about to close but I'm sure that's a wild experience.
author: Chris C.

description: I barely ever actually go into the store myself, but my parents always buy baked goods from here and bring them home.  My favorite has to be the pineapple buns with custard inside, delish, and i love eating their mini sponge cakes, i don't think i've seen any other places with the small ones besides Napolean's, other places are all bigger and sometimes kind of dry.  i like how Napolean's sponge cakes are always moist.  also the egg tarts are really good too
author: Stephanie T.

description:
They increase their price a bit couple months ago, but hey who can blame them, it's still cheap and good.
Sure you have to "fight"  to order but it's worth the effort though. And if you are adventurous eater enough try their "Durian Bread", it's yummy especially when it's still warm but if not just try their Chicken & Cheese, or the Pork Siung Bun, or the Ham & Cheese, or the........well they really have a lot to choose from.
author: toto h.

description:
What sets  competitive pastry establishments (Chinatown shops vs. Safeway, etc) apart from each other? Price, service, food quality, and, um.. not much else, dude(tte). 

Today my bday spirit got uplifted by this wonderful place - so THIS is where my ma purchases such delicious, huge baked good! Godamn, she is a secretive mother, she! 

Anyway I got a Taro bun, Pineapple/Custard bun, and a Red Bean one totaling up $2.50. Currently their selections range anywhere between .70 - $1/item, making them possibly the priciest damned bakery in Oakland, but have you seen the size of these whoppers! I'm not speaking about BK here, folks... they've earned my will of naming them the favorite bakery in my book. 

ROCK ON, SUPER NAPOLEAN!!!
author: Carl Z.

description: It's just passed... if i have not mistaken, this is the place with really good bakery goods, yet the service you get is like you are invisible. To the ladies behind the counter, they can care less for your business, so if you have experienced any discrimination while trying to rush on the bus and still having to wait more than 5 minutes for service, while the lady stares out in space behind the counter, you're at the right place. Unfortunately.
author: Monika T.

description: I've come to this bakery whenever I visit Chinatown forever! My mom always has to have her favorite pastry from here, the butter cream bun ($0.70). It's really hard to order here when it's "rush hour" and by rush hour I mean when it's packed with elderly Chinese people pushing and shoving trying to get their sugar cravings under control. When you do actually get to the front, be prepared to repeat things because most of the servers don't speak English at all which makes things very difficult if you can't speak Cantonese...even someone with limited Mandarin like me can have a hard time so I just stick to speaking clear English and pointing at things I want to order. Their butter cream buns are so yummy! Each at $.70, I usually buy 10 for my mom and the family. I also order their Cocktail buns (4 for $1.40) which are buns filled with what tastes like coconut stuffing? I am not really sure myself...and I get some egg tarts every now and then. I can't say they are better than the ones down the street, that one famous place with the line out to the corner of the block, but this place's egg tarts are all I can really remember so I order some every now and then. They are also $0.70 each.
author: Alex T.

description:
I just moved to North Beach from rainy Suburbia in Washington State. I came here with two suitcases and no job, so in-between interviews/general job hunting I've explored. I spent the first two days walking morning to night in Chinatown, wandering into every store. I've always loved red bean buns, but there were so hard to find back home, and not always fresh. The pastries at the Napoleon Super Bakery are FANTASTIC, and always fresh because they don't last long on the shelf.

I have to agree that you have to fight to get to the counter, but what good things aren't worth fighting for? Plus, the prices are cheap, which is very important to the temporarily jobless like me!
author: Jessica B.

description: I like their little savory buns, and their cakes when fresh and good, BUT man- major diva attitude here.  Also, not really a fan of their don tots (egg tarts).. too eggy of a crust.  Ruby King is better...better enough to withstand those hom sup los who hang out there and nurse their coffee for 2 hours...
author: K K.

description: well,this bakery has all sorts of buns and goods.It's cheap and it taste better than other stores(BAKERY!).So I think every visitor or anyone can buy anything here
author: Victoria L.

description: This is my to-go place for bakery items in Chinatown. I always get their Pineapple buns (with a bean-paste filling and also without). They are my favorite, they also have good egg tarts, if you come at a good time, you see them take it out fresh! I always go to the back of the store and get the fresh ones that just came out and I must say it's better than Golden Gate Bakery. The line isn't ridiculously long or expensive. It's just as good as Golden Gate Bakery but cheaper. You should also get their coconut tarts(? Not sure what exactly it's called). It's sitting on top above all the buns. It's above the "puff" (refer to photos). It was my first time having a coconut tart and I must say it's delicious. It's exactly like an egg tart but without the egg custard, instead it is coconut strips? It's a MUST GET. Their cakes are also not bad. I like them, sometimes it's too sweet for my liking. When I get their cakes, I always order a cake that is made for me with fresh fruits (paid extra for). They also have lemon swiss rolls I occasionally get. Trying their bread is good too. Buy a loaf of bread (either with butter or one that's salted). They made it themselves and it's pretty darn good. They would cut the butter load into slices for you but not the 'salted' bread. The 'salted' loaf has a piece of paper wrapped around it. I always get a big box filled with goodies from here every time I am in Chinatown. This place is crowded, there is no 'line' really you just stand in front, get their attention and order what you want. Cash only, they only have around 4 small tables here so don't expect to get something and sit here and eat. Cash only (but there are banks right around the area).
author: Tiffany Y.

description: i come here when they were about to close just brought what they had in the display case that look yummy.  I should try the red bean buns next time. I liketheir skinny cat that has strips it reminds me of my cat.  My grandmother said this place is cheap to buy the buns.
author: John F.

description:
2 red bean buns, 1 taro bun, 1 BBQ pork bun = $2.60

Steph: "No way! That's so cheap! Did they make a mistake?"

More Authentically Chinese Companion: "Dude, we Chinese people don't make math mistakes like that."

Since I barely qualify as a person of Chinese heritage (Steph Secret #9; see Ton Kiang review http://www.yelp.com/biz/4p7kNEeZnKVPQAoRbSlxjw?hrid=FXo2ZmM2FkKNip-Y6NPweQ), this fact escaped me.  As much as a disgrace as I am, I have at least eaten enough baked buns to be able to tell a good one from a bad one. Napoleon Super Bakery's baked buns are fresh and delicious! Upon the first bite, each of the buns was firmly indented, and I found myself chewing more than crunching - the true signs of a fresh bun! The huge red bean and taro buns (about 4'' or thumb-lengths in diameter) were just the right amount of sweetness. The yellow crunchy topping was also perfect - slightly sweet, not too dry/crumbly, and had a hint of almond flavor. The pork bun held up til the next day for breakfast, and I was delighted that the well-proportioned, tender pork filling was sweet, while maintaining its BBQ flavor integrity. 

The bakery is busy, but that's a good thing! I can't wait to return to my new Chinatown must-go-to and try out those amazing looking egg custards and other delicious treats. Maybe if I eat enough Chinese baked goods, my ass will get large enough for me to claim myself as at least 1/3 Chinese...
author: Steph P.

description: I've been to every Chinese bakery in San Francisco (and some in the South Bay) since 2000.  Yes, you get elbowed by Chinatown locals 45 years your senior.  Yes, you are sometimes studiously ignored by the 10 people behind the counter.  Yes, the hike down Stockton street can mean you have to walk in the middle of the road to avoid the produce hunting parties.  But for consistently great Chinese baked goods, come here for the real deal.  It's the best.
author: Chung-Man T.

description: Tasty buns overfilled with lots of stuffing, try the taro or red bean or if you are adventurous enough, also the durian altho some ppl might attest by the odor. There are more filling than dough itself. Most bakery items are $0.50 but definitely cheap and tasty. There is no orderly line and the staff don't encourage the line-up either. Just shove your way to the front and scream out your order.
author: Yan M.

description: the Lo Po Beng is pretty bomb. My cousin introduced me to them and i been hooked ever since. Ironically my cousin introduced me to these Lo Po Beng when i was in LA because she requested i pick some up from my latest trip home to SF. iono how i grew up as an ABC in SF and never recalled having Lo Po Beng despite the fact my parents frequent CT pretty often.
author: Tony L.

description: I agree - the red bean buns here are good and only 70 cents! They also have durian buns. :D
author: Laurie c.

description: I like Napolean for its good variety and price.  Everything is above average, except for its birthday cakes.  I bought a lemon flavored mousse cake and it tasted not so good.  I also tried the "dark forest" but not so good either.  It is definitely a good place to get "pineapple" bread and hot dog bread.
author: Jamie L.

description: The best Chinese baked goods in the bay area by far.
author: Mai E.

description:
I actually come here to buy birthday cakes.  When I'm in charge of getting a birthday cake for family or friends, this is the only place i think of.  It's filled with fruits and you can get it right away if you want one quick from the choices they have already made.  Never really had a bad comment about the cakes from anyone that tried it. 
The pastries are good and reasonably priced.  There s usually a lot of people in line (more like people pushing trying to order first even though they were not first in line). But its all good.
author: Jason C.

description: If you're on Atkins diet, then you definitely should not go here. Their breads are good (red bead bread and the sponge cake). It can get packed here especially at lunch. Their custard tart, I think, is second best to Golden Gate's.
author: JB L.

description: I like the egg custard pineapple buns! The mini ones!
author: Elaine H.

description: The best Chinese bakery in the Bay Area... actually, the best Chinese bakery that I've been to in the US... and I've been to a lot.  Their bolo bao and gai mei bao set them apart.  I've never been disappointed here.
author: Kristina W.

description:
I'm split at odds with this place.  I've "researched" a lot regarding which place in SF has the better cakes:  Napolean / AA Bakery / ABC / Sheng Kee / Sogo but concluded that this is the best tasting bakery in town....especially with their Mango Mousse.  Their cakes are inexpensive.

Unfortunately, I've also heard rumors that they were selling cakes with mold in the middle.  Sometimes, their cakes have egg shells in them!  So far, I haven't experience either of this...so that's why gave 3 stars.  I've also looked up their City Health inspection score:  42 out of 100.  Now I'm skeptical about returning to this place eventhough they're still the best tasting bakery.
author: Gary Y.

description: Lots of pastries to chose from. Used to love it here but then I saw a cute baby cockroach in the display case. If you see one then you know it's been in the food. Knowing stores in china town they probably still use the contaminate ingredients.
author: Keit K.

description: Their buns are decent . However , the cakes are ehhh not that good .. they are just acceptable . For cakes , I would go across the street to AA Bakery . They look and taste better .
author: Eileen L.

description: They got good loaves of bread.  It is like cheesy bread.  I don't think anything else was that super other than this.
author: Amy L.

description: Every Chinatown trip I make, I always end up coming in here and load up my carbs for the week. After squeezing my way in here and hailing the ladies behind the counter to take my order, I end up always ordering the same things, the baked pineapple custard bun, baked taro, and baked Durian are favorites of mine.  The baked buns are always tasty and filled with creamy/custard goodness.
author: Juliane N.

description: Whenever I'm in San Fransisco I always make it a point to visit this place.  They have THE best buns I've ever had-- ANYWHERE.  My favorites are the custard, the coconut and the bbq buns.  Getting in and out is an experience in itself---so many people trying to jockey their position and get noticed by the little ladies behind the counter. I always get more buns than I think I'm going to eat and ALWAYS wish I got a few more.  I usually grab my bag of buns and eat one (or two) standing on the sidewalk in front of the bakery.  It has occured to me that I probably appear in the background of some tourist's snapshot scarfing down a bun (or buns) with complete abandon. I guess I'm okay with that. I really have no shame when it comes to these buns. I'm tempted to quote Sir Mix-A-Lot here but I won't.
author: Linda S.

description: Beware. The bun i bought was stale. 200% a left over. HOW COULD THEY?
author: Jimmy C.

description: Nice bakery. Good bun selection but they don't always keep them warm.
author: Katherine C.

description: If you like "ma jai" (Chinese style rice krispies I guess? Made with flour, sugar and egg), you gotta get it here!  The softness is just right, so you don't break your teeth chewing one, and it's not too sticky on the teeth like some others.  It's a little bit sweeter than the normal ones, so for me it's perfect!  It's only 70 cents each but they don't always have it.
author: Peggy M.

description: My favorite bakery in Chinatown. It never loses it's originality. My mother always buys me the breads here and occasionally on my birthday, we purchase the cakes. Business is bustling in here so you better act fast when one of the ladies asks you what you want. Many of the customers are very ... feisty, so you better move fast. The breads are very tasty and inexpensive and are usually less than a dollar. The cakes are the best! They usually range from $13-20 something depending on how big you want it. It's a very great store if you want something inexpensive and for on-the-go as well.
author: Jenny L.

description: I was drawn to the super piggy cartoon holding the bread on the faded awning... I guess then I should have felt more guilty about devouring the delicious pork buns?
author: Katie T.

description: This bakery carries some good baked buns. My old favorites are corn with ham, bread loaves, red bean bun, and shredded pork bun. The presentation of the cakes doesn't look as nice as ABC's (across the street). I don't buy cakes from here - but the variety of the buns is amazing. The prices have gone up recently but it's still a steal. It's chaos during the busy peak hours (weekends, breakfast, and lunch hour) and you have to be aggressive to put your order in. There is no orderly line, lots of folk just cut in front of you without any qualms. Be aggressive! Otherwise you'll be standing there for a long time.
author: Candace F.

description:
often very crowded, so be prepared to fight your way to the people behind the counters to get served. the large crowd indicates how delicious this bakery is. [not to mention pretty downright cheap]
best buns around, especially the pineapple ones. the crust is flaky and crunchy.
author: Court L.

description: Tasty, tasty red bean buns. Unlike a lot of red bean goods, the buns at Napoleon don't taste sickeningly sweet. Instead, the buns are filled with whole red beans that are probably as good for you as they are tasty. I also tried the cheese and fish bun. It isn't disgusting like it might sound, and I like that it's made of fresh fish rather than fish paste. Unfortunately, it was soggy in some places, so I won't be getting that again. Five stars, nonetheless, because Napoleon gets an extra star for being so cheap. Eventually, I'll get to trying the huge walnut cookies, the mango or chocolate cake, the egg tart, and the ham and tomato buns. Updates then!
author: Anita L.

description: i've been here a couple of times, and it's always slow here (re: not busy).  i had their bbq pork bun, and it was gross, almost not edible.  i usually get my items from AA bakery across the street, but it's always so busy!  so since i was in a time crunch today, i decided to bypass the 10 minute wait at AA and get some egg tarts here.  though the egg tarts are cheap (70 cents vs the recently upped 85 cent price at AA), they were terrible.  okay to be honest, i have had worst egg tarts (like this place further south on stockton), but it doesn't mean that this egg tart was good.  the crust is orange, which is a little weird (who puts dye in their crust?).  their egg was too yellow (too much yellow dye?).  and their crust was soggy and their tart falls apart.  not only, you don't taste egg or sugar in the egg tart.  it was like biting into a soggy tasteless greasy sponge.
author: H. L.

description: ABSOLUTELY the BEST char sui bao in SF!  Belly up to the counter w the locals and place your order.......use ur fingers to indicate number of items you want if you are chinese-speaking challenged.  Enjoy!
author: kristy l.

description: This is the chinese bakery that my family and I go to most often. The tomato ketchup bun thingy is a must! XD Prices are always pretty cheap, which is a good thing.  ^_^
author: Cindy W.

description: I love their buns. I tried their cake once and it was light and fluffy. I usually copy what other people buy. You can't go wrong with everyone's favorites. It was a very good choice.
author: bob k.
